editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

THE HISTORY OF
PAINTING,

Containing their RISE, PROGRESS, DECAY, and REVIVAL; With an Account Of the mo≈øt con≈øiderable Productions of the be≈øt ARTISTS in all Ages: And how to di≈øtingui≈øh the true and regular Performances, from tho≈øe that are otherwi≈øe.
By P. MONIER, Painter to the French KING, and Profe≈ø≈øor of Painting, and Sculpture in the Royal Academy at PARIS.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: OF all the Products of human Wit, whereof the Brain a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Hand is capable, there are none ≈øo admirable and excellent, as the Arts which relate to De≈øigning.

The ancient Grecians were of this Opinion. They placed them among the Liberal Arts, and ≈øet ≈øo great a value on them, that their Slaves were forbidden to learn either Painting, Sculpture, or Architecture. There were only Gentlemen permitted the Honour to Exerci≈øe them: And even Princes them≈øelves gloried in the Practice of them.

The Romans, who endeavoured to imitate the Grecians in the Perfection of
the≈øe Arts, had the ≈øame E≈øteem for them; for ≈øeveral Con≈øuls and Emperors took plea≈øure in employing them≈øelves therein. And the≈øe Arts kept up their Excellency, while the Empire was in its heighth; but they began to decline when that became the Prey of ≈øeveral Tyrants who were the Cau≈øe of its Ruine. Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture underwent the like De≈øtiny, for they lo≈øt the Protection and E≈øteem they found under the fir≈øt Emperors, and at length fell into that ill and rude Manner, which has been ≈øince named Gothick or Barbarous. But afterwards they regain'd new life and vigour under the Protection of ≈øeveral Princes, and Republicks, and by the Indu≈øtry and Application of tho≈øe ingenious Men who ≈øtudied them.

It has not been without ju≈øt Rea≈øons that the≈øe Three illu≈øtrious Profe≈ø≈øions have always been valued and e≈øteemed at ≈øo high a rate, for their Beauties are always extremely plea≈øing to the Ingenious,
and there is nothing which more illu≈øtrates the Glory of Princes, than the Productions of De≈øigning. In ≈øhort, the famous Structures of the Egyptians, Grecians, and Romans eternize the Memory of tho≈øe Illu≈øtrious Per≈øons for who≈øe Glory they were rai≈øed: They are al≈øo inconte≈øtable Witne≈ø≈øes of the Victories which their Great Captains obtain'd over other Nations.

Such clear evidences are more Authentick than any Hi≈øtories, for they repre≈øent to us without any prejudice the Truth of tho≈øe Things, for which tho≈øe ancient Buildings were rai≈øed by the Art of De≈øigning: It was moreover by means of this Art that Medals were made, which ≈øerve to confirm ≈øome very doubtful Matters of Fact related by Hi≈øtory: And expre≈øs to us the Actions of Heroes, and tran≈ømit their Memory to Po≈øterity.

To the≈øe advantages may be added that of Military Architecture, which derives its Principles from this Art, and which is very nece≈ø≈øary for the Security
of Towns, and Defence of Kingdoms.

Nor have the Arts of De≈øigning been of le≈øs advantage to Princes in the Point of Religion, than for the Defence of their States. The Heathens were very Curious in, and made it a con≈øiderable Part of, their Religious Wor≈øhip to di≈øtingui≈øh the Forms they made their Temples of, according to the different Divinities they therein wor≈øhipp'd. Since that time ≈øeveral of tho≈øe Temples have been made u≈øe of At Rome ≈øeveral of the Popes by permi≈ø≈øion of the Emperors of Con≈øtantinople, converted ≈øeveral of the Heathen Temples into Chri≈øtian Churches, as that of the Pantheon, which is now the Church of Notre-Dame de la Rotonde, and that of Romulus was dedicated to St. Co≈ømus and St. Damian; and al≈øo that of Bacchus which is at pre≈øent called St. E≈øtienne the round. for the Wor≈øhip of the true God. But tho≈øe that have been built on purpo≈øe for the Chri≈øtian Religion ≈øurpa≈øs tho≈øe ancient Temples: And this may be ≈øeen in ≈øeveral Places, and
chiefly in St. Peter's, at Rome, the noble≈øt Church that was ever ≈øeen.
The Churches are adorn'd with Statues, with Ba≈øs Reliefs, and Pictures to repre≈øent the My≈øteries of our Religion, and the Martyrdoms of the Saints.

The≈øe Subjects managed by ingenious Painters, and Sculptors, make greater and more la≈øting Impre≈ø≈øions upon the Minds of People, than Words can. This was the Opinion of St. Gregory of Nice, and ≈øeveral other Great Men, who were ≈øen≈øibly touched at the ≈øight of the≈øe Repre≈øentations.

Moreover Nature, which con≈øtantly tends towards what is mo≈øt agreeable to its ≈øelf, taught Men De≈øigning before they had found out Characters to Write. This Truth is evident in the Hi≈øtorical Figures (or Hieroglyphicks) of the Egyptians, Engraven on Stone, as may be ≈øeen on their Obelisks. For tho≈øe Sorts of Letters are only the De≈øigns of Figures made of ≈øome Parts of the Human Body, of Animals, of Plants,
and of all ≈øorts of In≈øtruments, which were called Hieroglyphicks, and whereof this People made u≈øe before they had Letters.

Cornelius Tacitus in the Eleventh .... Ac novas literarum formas addidit vulgavit
que Comperio quo
que graecam literaturam non ≈øimul caeptam ab≈øolutamque; Primi per Figuras animalium Aegyptii ≈øen≈øus mentis effingebant, & antiqui≈ø≈øima monumenta memoriae humanae impre≈ø≈øa Saxis cernuntur, & literarum ≈øemet inventores perhibent. Book of his Annals favours this Opinion: And it may be very well conjectured that De≈øigning and Painting preceded Writing; nay, within the≈øe few Ages we have had an almo≈øt undeniable Proof of it. At the di≈øcovery of America, we find, that De≈øigning was practi≈øed there, although tho≈øe People had no knowledge of Letters or Writing: And that particularly in the Kingdom of Mexico, where we find, they wrought in Painting and Sculpture.

For among ≈øeveral rich Pre≈øents which their King Monteczuma made to
Ferdinand Cortes, there was a Book of Figures
General Hi≈øtory of the Indies by Francis Lopez de Gomara. Their Palaces were adorned with Statues, and there were ≈øome of Gold. Pag. 94 and 128.
They under≈øtood al≈øo Geography by De≈øigning, Pag. 98. See moreover in that Hi≈øtory, Pag. 64. 78. 109. 130. 140. 141. and 157. in≈øtead of Letters, re≈øembling the Hieroglyphicks of the Egyptians: And Painting was ≈øo much in u≈øe there, that this Prince ≈øhewed to the ≈øaid Captain one of his Courriers, who brought him, painted on a Piece of Cloath, ≈øome Spani≈øh Succours, which were newly arrived.

Upon this Cloath were repre≈øented the Ve≈ø≈øels, the Men, the Artillery, the Hor≈øes, and the Dogs, whereof tho≈øe Recruits con≈øi≈øted. The advantage which Cortes moreover in particular received by means of this Painting was very con≈øiderable; for ≈øome Indian Lords having con≈øpired to kill him, he was adverti≈øed thereof by
one of them who ≈øhewed him a Cloath, whereon were de≈øigned the Portraits of all the Con≈øpirators, and by the≈øe happy means this Captain e≈øcaped the danger.

The advantage and excellency of the Arts of De≈øigning ≈øhew the difficulty of attaining to
Vigenerus, Pag. 853. Perfection in them, by rea≈øon they require a great deal of Knowledge, to ≈øucceed well in the Practice of them: For be≈øides a natural Inclination for them, the Rules of them mu≈øt be very nicely ≈øtudied; and care mu≈øt be taken to match good In≈øtructions and a natural Genius for them, together; otherwi≈øe it will be impo≈ø≈øible to become Excellent in them.

The≈øe difficulties, in the three la≈øt Ages, ≈øtirr'd up an Emulation among ≈øeveral great Princes, jealous of their own Glory, and the Qualifications of
their Subjects. They e≈øtabli≈øhed Academies of De≈øigning at Florence, then at Rome, and Bolonia, and afterwards at Antwerp, and la≈øtly at Paris, where the Painters, Sculptors, and Architects The Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture was founded in 1648. And His Maje≈øty began in 1665 another Academy at Rome to perfect the Di≈øciples of the Academy Royal; which continues to this pre≈øent time. compo≈øe illu≈øtrious Bodies.

Tho≈øe which The King moreover e≈øtabli≈øhed another particular Academy for Architecture in 1671. Lewis XIV. has erected in his Metropolis, have been the mo≈øt powerful means that could be invented, to make excellent Painters, Sculptors and Architects. There Youth is taught to De≈øign after Nature, There are al≈øo taught the Doctrines of Proportions, Geometry, Per≈øpective, and Anatomy: And every Month there are Conferences upon
whatever relates to the In≈øtruction of their Di≈øciples.

Among the Lectures which I have had the Honour to read there, upon the Concours, or Out-lines of Bodies; upon Per≈øpective, Anatomy, and the Motions of the Mu≈øcles: And al≈øo on the Progre≈øs, Fall and Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the Arts of De≈øigning, I have cho≈øe the≈øe latter Conferences to Form out of them the Hi≈øtory of the Arts which relate thereunto.

In the Fir≈øt Book, I treat of the Original and Progre≈øs of Architecture, Sculpture and Painting, from the Fir≈øt Ages of the World, till after the time of the Emperor Marcus Aurelius, when the≈øe Arts began to decline. Throughout all this Tract of Time we take notice of the Curio≈øity of the Kings of A≈ø≈øyria, Egypt, Phoenicia, Per≈øia and I≈ørael to rai≈øe huge and extraordinary Buildings. We there remark how the≈øe Arts went from the Phoenicians to the Grecians and Carthaginians:
And how afterwards they went into Italy, and the Progre≈øs they made in Tu≈øcany, and at Rome in the Times of their Kings, of the Republick, and of the Emperors; la≈øtly, we ≈øhew in what E≈øteem they were there, and how far Protected till their decay.

In the Second Book, we treat of their Fall, and ≈øhew how the true Manner and Gu≈øt of De≈øigning began to decline at Rome, after Commodus down to Con≈øtantine; and afterwards, Architecture al≈øo decay'd: In≈øomuch that an ill and rude Manner was introduced in Building, in Painting and Sculpture. The Zeal of the Chri≈øtian Religion contributed very much to the De≈øtruction of the ancient Temples, and Images, as did al≈øo the taking of Rome, the Reigns of the Goths and Lombards, who followed that rude Manner in Italy, and propagated it almo≈øt throughout all Europe.

But the Magnificence of Architecture was maintained longer in the Ea≈øtern Empire than in other Places, and e≈øpecially at Con≈øtantinople, by rea≈øon that the Fir≈øt Emperors were very much addicted to Architecture, as we ≈øee in Con≈øtantius, Theodo≈øius, and in Ju≈øtinian, who Employed va≈øt Trea≈øures in Building, which for ≈øome time kept up Architecture, Sculpture and Painting: The≈øe two la≈øt ≈øuffered very much, ≈øince the time of tho≈øe Princes, by the Iconocla≈øtes, who de≈øtroy'd the Images, and barbarou≈øly per≈øecuted the Painters, and at length the≈øe Arts fell entirely in that Empire, in the Reigns of the Mahometans, who ≈øuffer none to De≈øign the human Figure, nor any thing that has life.

In the Third Book, we ≈øhew that about the Year 1110, the Arts of De≈øigning began to revive a little at Florence, and in ≈øome other Cities of Italy; the Protection they afterwards found under the Kings of Naples, of
France, the Republicks of Venice and Florence, the great Dukes of Tu≈øcany, and the Popes of that Illu≈øtrious Hou≈øe, and ≈øeveral other Princes of Italy, gave means and opportunity to ≈øeveral excellent Genius's to apply them≈øelves with a great deal of Zeal to the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture. In fine in the Year 1500 I conclude the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the≈øe Arts, for it was in this happy Century that they were brought to Perfection by the Famous De≈øigners who flouri≈øhed about that time.

This has been acknowledged by all the Famous De≈øigners of our Age: Who have e≈øteemed it their Glory to Imitate the Works of Raphael, Correggio, Julio Romano, and Titian, and ≈øeveral other Ingenious Men of the la≈øt Age.

For it has been by means of this imitation that the true Way
of Painting and De≈øigning has continued down to us; as al≈øo the right Manner of Sculpture and Architecture: As has been practi≈øed from the beginning of this Century 1600. by the Famous Carraches, and afterwards by their Di≈øciples Domenichino, Albani, Guido, Lanfranc, Algradi. Afterwards the true Way and Manner was continued in the≈øe Three Arts at Rome by Pou≈ø≈øin, Francis du Que≈ønoy, Peter da Cortona and Bernini. As al≈øo in Flanders by Rubens and Van Dyck: Moreover France by de Bro≈ø≈øe, Le Mercier, Le Sueur, Sarrazin, Man≈øard, Bourdon, Le Brun Mignard, and ≈øeveral other great Men who have flouri≈øhed in the Arts of De≈øigning.

But this true and regular Manner is kept up very ≈øucce≈øsfully at pre≈øent by tho≈øe Ingenious Men who compo≈øe the Royal Academies of
Painting, Sculpture and Architecture: Having determin'd to follow the Foot≈øteps of the Ingenious Ancients, and the incomparable Maxims of tho≈øe excellent Genius's who appear'd with ≈øo much Glory in the Age before them. We may perhaps hereafter pre≈øent the Reader with a Continuation of this Hi≈øtory throughout the Century 1600, which we re≈øerve for a Second Volume.

Nor ought it to ≈øurprize any, That a Painter ≈øhould undertake to write an Hi≈øtory of De≈øigning, becau≈øe among other Accompli≈øhments he ought to be Ma≈øter of, that of being well ver≈øed in Hi≈øtory is none of the lea≈øt; for thereby he makes his Works conformable to Truth, and can give a Rea≈øon of his Repre≈øentations: And joining the Theory of his Art with the Practice, he becomes expert
enough to compo≈øe a Sy≈øtem of the Rules of it, far better than tho≈øe who are not De≈øigners.

This was practi≈øed by the mo≈øt Famous Painters of Antiquity, as Apelles, and his Di≈øciple Per≈øeus, and
A≈øclepiodorus, Protogenes, Euphranor, and Praxiteles writ of Painting and Sculpture, as did Argellius and Vitruvius of Architecture. others: The Illu≈øtrious Moderns have al≈øo written of the Arts of De≈øigning, as Leon Bapti≈øta Alberti, Leonardo da Vinci, and ≈øeveral others The chief of the Modern Painters who have writ of Painting ≈øince Leon Bapti≈øta Alberti, and Leonardo da Vinci, are Va≈øari, Armenini, P. Lomazzo, F. Zucchero, Albert Dal Borgo San Sepolcro, Albert Durer, John Cou≈øin, Charles Alphon≈øus du Fre≈ønoy; and the chief of tho≈øe who have writ of Architecture be≈øides Leon Bapti≈øta Alberti are Vignola, Palladio, Scammozzi, Serlio, Barbaro, Cataneo, Philbert de Lorme, John Bullant, and du Cerceau. who have treated learnedly
of the≈øe Arts for the Advantage of tho≈øe who de≈øign to be Excellent therein.

The rea≈øon why we have rather given this Treati≈øe the Title of the Arts that relate to De≈øigning than the Hi≈øtory of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture, is becau≈øe De≈øigning not only comprehends tho≈øe Three Parts, but al≈øo graving on Copper, cutting in Wood, and graving for Medals, and Damask-work, and Embroidery, and Inlaying and ≈øeveral other Works all depending on De≈øigning.

For this Rea≈øon all the≈øe Arts are put together, and compo≈øe tho≈øe Academies, which are called in Italy, Academies of De≈øigning, where Painters, Sculptors and Architects take upon them ≈øucce≈ø≈øively the fir≈øt Places: And for this Rea≈øon they who intend
for any of the≈øe Profe≈ø≈øions, fir≈øt of all learn De≈øigning, and then determine their Choice to ≈øome one in Particular, or ≈øometimes to more, being capable of ≈øucceeding therein, if they are fir≈øt of all good De≈øigners.

This has been evident heretofore in Daedalus, Phidias Euphranor, and ≈øeveral others, who were as Excellent in Sculpture and Painting as in Architecture, and al≈øo of late in Ghiberto who was a Painter, Architect, Sculptor and Gold≈ømith: Verochio and Leonardo da Vinci were al≈øo Ma≈øters of all the≈øe Arts, as likewi≈øe Bramante, Raphael, Julio Romano, Balda≈ø≈øare, Vignola and Pirro Ligorio who were Painters and Architects: Michael Angelo was equally Excellent in Architecture, Sculpture and Painting, for he was an Excellent De≈øigner.

Hence it is, we have taken our Device on the Fronti≈øpeice of this Book, which expre≈ø≈øes, that De≈øigning is the Parent of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture. And now we cannot but expect that Criticks will be making Reflections on the Style we have u≈øed throughout this Hi≈øtory: But that the Reader may not ≈øtick or carp if he meets with any ob≈øolete Terms or Words not much in u≈øe, and if the Turn of the Phra≈øe is not always ≈øo Nice as he might expect: He mu≈øt know, that the Author's De≈øign is only to make him≈øelf under≈øtood by tho≈øe who learn De≈øigning. Wherefore he hopes that the unprejudiced Reader will not ≈øo nicely regard the Politene≈øs of Expre≈ø≈øion, ≈øince his Bu≈øine≈øs is Painting, and he looks upon the re≈øt only as accidental Accompli≈øhments.

If this Hi≈øtory find a favourable Acceptance, we de≈øign hereafter to
give an Alphabetical Explication of the Terms mo≈øt u≈øed in the Arts of De≈øigning, whence ≈øeveral Ob≈øervations may be rai≈øed very nece≈ø≈øary for the In≈øtruction of the Di≈øciples and Lovers of the≈øe Arts.

div.p: JULIUS CAESAR no lefs affected building than tho≈øe great Men who went before him: His Palace, and the Circus The great Circus built by Cae≈øar the Dictator was three Stadia or Furlongs in length, and one broad, and encompa≈ø≈øed with all its appurtenances four Acres. which he augmented, are ≈øufficient Proofs of it. Domitian
Domitian not only rebuilt the Temple of Jupiter Capitolinus more Magnificent than it had been before; but al≈øo his Palace where nothing was finer than the Galleries in the Porticus, the Halls, the Baths, and Apartments for his Women; he was ≈øo much enamour'd with Building, that like Midas he could have wi≈øh'd every thing he touch'd might be turn'd into Gold and Stones. div.head: CHAP. II.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: The Dominion of the Goths in Italy brought in the rude Way.

div.p: AFTER the Arts of De≈øigning were declined at Rome, in the time of the latter Empire, by all tho≈øe unhappy Accidents that happened to that City, they al≈øo underwent the ≈øame Fate in the Provinces of Italy, where the Goths and other barbarous Nations de≈øtroy'd the fine Roman Buildings, whereof there remain only ≈øome famous Foot≈øteps of their Ruine.

Theodoricus one of their Kings having e≈øtabli≈øhed the Seat of his Kingdom at Ravenna, his Reign was long, glorious and peaceful; and as he very much loved Building, he apply'd him≈øelf in his Capital at Rome, and in the principal Places of Romania, and Lombardy to build ≈øeveral Palaces and Churches, which are yet to be ≈øeen, all of them of a rude Way, very remote from good Principles of Architecture, and the exact Rules of the Antients. The Gothick Architects chiefly embelli≈øh'd their Works with Capricious Ornaments, which were to be ≈øeen on the Capitels of their Pillars: They adorn'd their Works with a great number of ≈ømall delicate Parts, and ≈øeveral Threds which re≈øembled O≈øiers, quite contrary to the Antient Architecture: This Gothick Way
is ≈øtill to be ≈øeen in the Churches of Ravenna and other Places which Theodoricus built King Theodoricus cau≈øed Palaces to be built at Ravenna, Pavia and Modena after a barbarous Way, which were rather great and rich than well built, or of good Architecture. The ≈øame may be ≈øaid of the Church of St. E≈øtienne de Rimini, of that of St. Martin at Ravenna, and the Temple of St. John built in the ≈øame City in the Year 438. by Galla Placidia. In the ≈øame City the Church of St. Vital was built in 547. This is remarkable in the Round Church of St. Mary near this City: The Vault of this Edifice is one only Stone, which al≈øo made the Cupolo, which is thirty This Author ≈øpeaks with certainty thereof, having mea≈øured it him≈øelf. div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: In the time of the Lombards the Gothick Way continued in Italy, and in ≈øeveral other Parts of Europe.

div.p:
THE Gothick Way in the Arts, was continued in Italy after the Goths by the Lombards, who drove them out thence, and reigned there two hundred and eighteen Years. This appears
not only in the Churches of Pavia, of Milan, of Bre≈ø≈øe, and other Buildings built by Luitprand, and their other
Luitprand built at Pavia the Church of St. Peter il ciel dauro. Va≈øari P. 77. Kings, but al≈øo in all the other Churches in France that were built about that time.

For after the French had got the Ma≈øtery of the Romans, they bani≈øh'd thence the Arts of De≈øigning, and no more regarded the Excellent Idea's of the Antient Architecture, ≈øuch as was to be ≈øeen at Orange, Ni≈ømes, St. Remi, Bordeaux and other Places where the Romans had made good Architecture to flouri≈øh.

But far from that the≈øe French Arti≈øts forgot, and laid a≈øide the true Method and Rules of the Antient Architecture: In≈øomuch, that the Way called Gothick grew into U≈øe with all the Nations of the We≈øt.

Hence it is that the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul built at Paris, by Clovis the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King, and called at this day St. Genevieve, is of this Gothick Way, and quite contrary to the Rules of good Architecture: One may al≈øo take notice of this rude Way of Architecture in the Church of St. Germain-des-Prez, built by Childebert Son of this King; here one may ob≈øerve the ill State and Condition of De≈øigning and Sculpture on the Capitels and four Ba≈øs Reliefs of the Choir of this Church, and in the Figures of the Porticus: For all the Sculptures there, are done without De≈øign, Reli≈øh or Art.

We may pa≈øs the ≈øame Judgment on the Painting of tho≈øe Times as on the Sculpture, for when the true Genius of De≈øign was wanting in the one, it was al≈øo deficient in the other: The Church of St. Martin de Tours is a Proof of this. There is to be ≈øeen over the great Vault a Crucifix of a ≈øort of Painting not at all exceeding the Graving in the ≈øame Church, which is after the antient Gothick Way.

In the Reign of Dagobert was built the Church of St. Dennis in France, which is of the ≈øame Sort with tho≈øe other Buildings, though made with great care and neatne≈øs. This Prince built ≈øeveral Churches after the ≈øame Way in Al≈øatia, and ≈øeveral other Provinces of Germany, which he Conquered, and where he left as Marks of his Piety, ≈øeveral Abbies which he founded.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: From the Time of Charlemain, the true Reli≈øh of Building altered le≈øs in To≈øcany than in other Countries.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: Reflections on the Fall of the Arts of De≈øigning, and on the Gothick Way.

div.p: THE Gothick Way continued after Charlemain, during the ≈øecond Race of our Kings, and under the Reigns of mo≈øt part of the third; under the≈øe la≈øt Princes there was no Change, neither in Architecture nor Sculpture, which is the rea≈øon we ≈øee nothing well ordered in their Palaces: This is apparent in the Palace of King Robert at St. Martin, and that of St. Lewis at Paris. The≈øe Buildings have nothing but the Gothick Way in them. This method continued after this King: And is to be ≈øeen in No≈øtre-Dame at Paris, which his Succe≈ø≈øors fini≈øhed.

All the Beauty of this Church con≈øi≈øts in its va≈øt Greatne≈øs and fine Plane, and ingenious Cutting of the Stones, and ≈øome delicate ≈ømall Parts or Pieces of Architecture, which notwith≈øtanding ≈øu≈øtain great Weights. Notwith≈øtanding the true Orders of Architecture, and good Sculpture is there wanting; every thing is after the Antient Gothick Way, which was followed in France till the Reign of Lewis the XII.

By what has been ≈øaid in this Book, we may conclude, that the Arts of De≈øign decay'd as ≈øoon as the Princes of the latter Empire grew out of love with them, and no longer protected them: This Neglect of them began the Ruine of the≈øe Arts, which encrea≈øed during the Civil Wars, by the ≈øackings of Rome, and the de≈øolation of the Provinces of its Empire. The Infidels and
the Hereticks contributed much to this Misfortune in ≈øeveral Places, and that even to the total De≈øtruction of the≈øe illu≈øtrious Profe≈ø≈øions.

But that the Reflections we make on the Fall of the≈øe Arts may be u≈øeful to tho≈øe who learn De≈øigning, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to know wherein con≈øi≈øts the ill and rude Way which was introduced in the time of their Declen≈øion, that it may be avoided for the Future.

It may be remarked in the fir≈øt Place in the Gothick Pieces, that what they had of Rude or Ill in them, proceeded from the Ignorance of tho≈øe that made them, in the ju≈øt Proportions of the human Figure, which is the ≈øolid Foundation of ju≈øt De≈øigning; ≈øince all their Statues are di≈øproportionate. For the mo≈øt Part have their Heads either too great or too little, the Hands and the extreme Parts too thin and ≈ølender, their Po≈øtures without any choicene≈øs, nay without intention or expre≈ø≈øion. Al≈øo in the cloathing of their Figures, are to be ≈øeen Cloaths cut in Pleats and Folds where naturally there are none; in ≈øhort, their Works have nothing that can plea≈øe the View or de≈øerve the Attention of tho≈øe that are Curious.

The≈øe are faults which ought to be avoided, as wrong Principles, by the Pupils of De≈øigning: Who ought to apply them≈øelves immediately to the ju≈øt Proportions of the Antients, for therein con≈øi≈øt the true Beauties of the Art.

They ought to begin with the Studies of Geometry and Per≈øpective, and with the Po≈øtures which naturally expre≈øs the different Actions of the Body, and Pa≈ø≈øions of the Soul. They ought to take care to learn Anatomy, that they
may know the Motions of the Mu≈øcles, and ob≈øerve their ju≈øt Contor≈øions.

The≈øe are the means which ought to be followed to arrive to the Knowledge of the true Beauty and Excellency of the≈øe Arts: It has been hereby, that the excellent Modern Painters, and Engravers, and Architects have made ≈øuch advances, to whom we are obliged for the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of Painting, of Sculpture, and of Architecture: Which ≈øhall be the Subject of the Third BOOK of this Hi≈øtory.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: The Arts began to flouri≈øh again in To≈øcany, in Architecture and Sculpture.

div.p:
AFTER having ≈øhewed in the Second Book of this Hi≈øtory, the cau≈øes of the declen≈øion and fall of Painting, and Sculpture, and Architecture, by the ill and rude Methods, and decay from that Excellence which they had arrived to among the ancient Grecians and Romans; we will ≈øhew in this Third Book how the≈øe Arts by little and little emerged from the rude Gothick way, and continued their Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment from the year 1013, to the end of 1500; wherein they arrived to their primitive Perfection, and pa≈ø≈øed from Italy into ≈øeveral other Parts, and particularly into France, by the ≈øingular Favour they found under our Kings, Francis the Fir≈øt, Henry

The≈øe Arts of De≈øigning began fir≈øt to be revived in To≈øcany, before they were known in other Countries. div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the Time when Painting began to be Re-e≈øtabli≈øhed at Florence.

div.p: PAINTING which was almo≈øt lo≈øt, began to revive again in the Church of St. Miniate at Florence, as is to be ≈øeen in the Mo≈øaick Painting of the Choir: This was done about the Year 1013, and till the Year 1211 wherein Cimab√ºe was born, we do not ≈øee that that Art acquired much perfection.

John Cimabo√ºe was born at Florence with a natural Genius and Inclination to De≈øigning, which made him neglect other Studies to which he was de≈øign'd by his Father: For he deceived his Tutors, and was continually amu≈øing him≈øelf in gratifying the Inclination and Tendency of his Genius. The opportunity which he had of the Society of two Grecian Painters, who came to Florence to Paint the Chappel of Gondis, was very lucky for him to ≈øatisfy his Inclination that Way: And when his Father ≈øaw him employ all his time in ≈øeeing them Work, he began to de≈øpair of his Sons ≈øucceeding in Learning, and ≈øo e'ne let him learn to Paint of the≈øe two Greeks.

The Genius and Application which Cimabo√ºe had for De≈øign, made him ≈øoon ≈øurpa≈øs his Ma≈øters: In≈øomuch that his Works di≈øtingui≈øhing them≈øelves from the ill and rude Ways, which were then in u≈øe, ≈øpread his Reputation through all the Neighbouring Towns, where he made ≈øeveral Pieces; this began to rai≈øe Painting again,
and gained this Painter the
The Reputation of Cimabo√ºe was ≈øo Great, that he was cho≈øen Architect with Arnolphus Lapo, to order the Fabrick of the Church of St. Mary Delfiore at Florence, where he was buried after having lived ≈øixty Years. There are the≈øe Words for his Epitaph;

At the ≈øame time with Cimabos flouri≈øh'd Andrew Tafi, a Florentine Painter in Mo≈øaick, he went to Venice to compleat him≈øelf in the ART, having under≈øtood that there were Grecian Painters there, who work'd after that Way at the Church of Saint Mark. He engaged Mae≈øtro Apollonio one of them to come and Work with him at Florence, where they made ≈øeveral Pieces, and Tafi learned of this Grecian the way of making Enamels, and Plai≈øters that would la≈øt a long time; he died in the Year 1294. But the greate≈øt Honour which Cimabos received, was when the King of Naples, Charles d'Anjou, went to ≈øee him Work on the Picture of St. Mary Novella. This Honour cau≈øed a particular Joy in the Citizens of that City, in≈øomuch that they made Fea≈øts and publick Rejoycings.

Charles of Anjou fir≈øt King of Naples, al≈øo very much honour'd Nicholas Pi≈øan the Engraver and Architect; he made him build ≈øeveral Churches, as the Abby in the Plain of Tagliacozzo, where he defeated Conradio; he built al≈øo other Churches, in ≈øeveral Places of To≈øcany: John Pi≈øan was Son of Nicholas, and was al≈øo Engraver and Architect: In 1283 he was at Naples and built there for King Charles the new Ca≈øtle there, and ≈øeveral Churches, and being returned into Tu≈øcany he made ≈øeveral Pieces of Sculpture at Arezze, and al≈øo of Architecture in that Province; he dy'd in 1320. Thus De≈øigning and Painting began to Emerge out of Ignorance, wherein they had lain buried for above nine hundred Years in Italy; and Heaven then began to favour them, vi≈øibly pouring out its Gifts on the Per≈øon of Ghiotto Pupil of Cimabos. For when he was a young Child, and in the Country guarded his Fathers Flocks, he practi≈øed De≈øigning with a ≈øharp pointed Stone for a Pencil on the Ground which he had made ≈ømooth on purpo≈øe, where he drew the Figures of his Sheep. In a ≈øhort Time Ghiotto learnt of his Ma≈øter the Principles of the Art, and far ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed him therein, by the ≈øtudy and imitation of Nature, applying him≈øelf chiefly to draw Pourtraictures and Hi≈øtories, which gain'd him ≈øo much Reputation, That Pope Benedict the IX. ≈øent for him to Rome, where he drew ≈øeveral Pieces in the Church of St. Peter. div.head: CHAP. IV.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: The French and the Dutch apply'd them≈øelves to make Painting reflouri≈øh, and found out the Secret of Painting in Oyl.

div.p:
THE Florentines, and the other Italians, were not the only Per≈øons who labour'd to perfect Painting: For ≈øome others on this ≈øide of the Mountains contributed much thereunto, although they had not the ≈øame advantages for De≈øigning, as tho≈øe of Italy, in having for Models
and Patterns the fine Ba≈øs-Reliefs of the Ancients.

The Genero≈øity of Charles the VIth contributed very much towards it among the French; and was the fir≈øt means to engage our Nation to Employ more than ordinary care on Painting, and particularly on Gla≈øs, which is called Gla≈øs-Painting This is ≈øo true, that in the time of Pope Julius the Second, there was at Rome Claudius Francis, who was a Painter on Gla≈øs; it was he who ≈øurvey'd all tho≈øe ≈øorts of Works, which were made in the Churches, and the Pope's Palace. Marcilla did al≈øo ≈øome of the ≈øame ≈øort of Paintings in the Apartments of the Vatican, and in the Church of St. Mary, and in that de l'Anima; after which the Cardinal de Corton carried him to his City, where he Painted both on Gla≈øs, and in Fre≈øco, ≈øeveral Pieces, which were very much e≈øteemed, for he was an Excellent De≈øigner, full of Invention and Variety in Compo≈øing of his Hi≈øtories; this appears particularly in the great Windows of the Chappel of the Albergotis, in the Cathedral of Arezzo, which Marcilla painted after having work'd at Corton; they are ≈øo Excellent, that Va≈øari calls them Divine, both for the fine Expre≈ø≈øions of Chri≈øt, calling St. Matthew from the receipt of Cu≈øtom, and of the other Apo≈øtles, as well as for the fine Architecture, and the Landskips which adorn that Hi≈øtory. Marcelli was ≈øo much con≈øidered in that City, that it obliged him to ≈øtay there till his Death, which happened in 1537. He had ≈øeveral Di≈øciples, whereof George Va≈øari was one; Va≈øari, Vita of William da Marcilla. , and which is u≈øed in Churches, wherein the French have ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed the Italians, and other Nations.

For this King to It was in the Year 1430. that King Charles the 6th granted new Priviledges to Henry Mellein, Painter and Glafier, and to all of that Art, in Confirmation of tho≈øe that had been granted by the Kings, his Predece≈ø≈øors, to Painters and Glaziers, which proves that there were then Painters in France, and that if the Art was not then in its Perfection, it was not for want of Protection from our Sovereigns, ≈øince to animate their Subjects to the Exerci≈øe of ≈øo noble an Art, they exempted them from all ≈øorts of Impo≈øts. Flanders which had been anciently a Province of this Kingdom, apply'd it ≈øelf at that time very much to Painting, and above all to drawing of Portraits, which drew the Flemings from the Gothick Manner, and by this means Painting arrived to Perfection in that Province, by rea≈øon of the great number of Painters, which were in all the Low-Countries, and of the con≈øiderable Commerce they made of their Pictures in Foreign Countries.

But among all the≈øe Painters, he to whom the Art is the mo≈øt obliged, is John Van-Eick, ≈øurnamed of Bruges, becau≈øe he came to inhabit there. He was an Extraordinary Chymi≈øt, and by help of that Art he found out new Varni≈øhes for his Pictures, that wanted it, as do all tho≈øe that are wrought in Di≈øtemper.

But one Day as he had fini≈øhed a Picture with a great deal of Care and Time, he varni≈øh'd it, and ≈øet it to dry in the Sun; but as ≈øoon as he perceived that the Heat had warp'd it, and crack'd it ≈øo that one might ≈øee through the Joints of it, which ≈øpoil'd it: To avoid ≈øuch Accidents for the future, he found he mu≈øt ≈øeek out for a Varni≈øh that might dry in the Shade; and becau≈øe he found that the Oyl of Wall-Nuts and Lin≈øeed, were the mo≈øt drying, he made u≈øe of them with ≈øome other Drugs, and ≈øo made a new Varni≈øh, which no Painter in the World had yet found out, and which was ≈øo earne≈øtly de≈øired.

After this he tri'd to mix his Colours with the≈øe Oyls, and ≈øeeing that they were not endamaged by Water, but that that made the Colour ≈øink ≈øomewhat the deeper, and that it ≈øhined without Varni≈øh; He found out by this means, with a great deal of Joy, that profitable Invention of Painting in Oyl. He made thereof ≈øeveral Pictures, the Reputation whereof pre≈øently ≈øpread it ≈øelf throughout all Europe; and this excited a great Curio≈øity in Painters to know how John of Bruges made his Painting ≈øo perfect. In the mean time he kept his Secret to him≈øelf, and permitted no body to ≈øee him Work, that he might make ≈øo much the more advantage of his Di≈øcovery.

But this Painter becoming old, imparted his Secret to Roger of Bruges, his Pupil, and Roger communicated it to Au≈ø≈øe, who was his, which
gave occa≈øion to bring Painting in Oyl into u≈øe, and to the Flemi≈øh-Merchants to make an advantageous Trafick of it throughout the World, although the way of Painting in Oyl did not go out of Flanders for ≈øeveral Years, till the time that certain Florentine-Merchants ≈øent out of the Low-Countries a Picture of John of Bruges, to Alphon≈øus, the fir≈øt King of Naples. This Picture for the Beauty of the Figures, and the Invention of the Colouring, was very much e≈øteemed by this Prince, and all the Painters of his Kingdom, and among the re≈øt by Antonello da Me≈ø≈øina, who had ≈øo vehement a de≈øire to learn the Secret of Painting in Oyl, that he immediately went from thence to Bruges in Flanders.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Of the Invention of Painting in Oyl, and its advantage in Painting, and how the Secret went into Italy.

div.p:
ANtonello da Me≈ø≈øina was ≈øcarce arrived in Flanders, but he contracted an acquaintance with John of Bruges, by Pre≈øents which he made him, of ≈øeveral Pieces of De≈øigning after the Italian way; and John ≈øeeing him≈øelf Old, re≈øolved to teach Antonelle to Paint in Oyl, and he did not leave off till he had perfectly attain'd that way. Antonello, after the Death of John van Eick, returned into Italy to impart the Secret he had learnt; but when he had been ≈øome Months at Me≈ø≈øina,
he went to Venice
Antonello dy'd at Venice at 49 Years of Age, and the Painters of that City perform'd his Ob≈øequies with a great deal of Honour; and in Memory of the Secret which he had ≈øhewed them of Painting in Oyl, they Engrav'd on his Tomb this Epitaph,
Antonius Pictor, proecipuum Me≈ø≈øaniae ≈øuae, & Siciliae totius Ornamentum hac humo contegitur. Non ≈øolum ≈øuis Picturis, in quibus ≈øingulare artificium, & venu≈øtas fuit, ≈øed, & quod coloribus oleo mi≈øcendis ≈øplendorem, & perpetuitatem primus Italicae Picturae contulit: ≈øummo ≈øemper Artificum Studio celebratus. About this time appear'd at Padua, Vellano the Sculptor, Di≈øciple of Donatello, who fini≈øh'd in that City the Work which his Ma≈øter had left imperfect; he was at Rome, and work'd for Pope Paul, the Venetian, in the Year 1464. Al≈øo Paulus Romanus, a Sculptor, di≈øtingui≈øh'd him≈øelf at Rome; he was Employed by Pope Pius the Second; the Figure of St. Paul, which is at the Entrance of the Bridge of St. Angelo is his.
This Paulus was al≈øo an excellent Worker in Gold; he made al≈øo the Apo≈øtles in Silver, which were on an Altar in the Pope's Chappel, and which were pillaged by the Imperiali≈øts at the taking Rome. One of his Contemporaries in Sculpture, was Mino; he made the two Figures of St. Peter and St. Paul, which are placed in the Entrance of that Church, and the Sepulchre of Paul the Second in the ≈øame Church. , where he e≈øtabli≈øh'd him≈øelf, and made ≈øeveral Pictures, which were e≈øteemed by the Nobles, and by all tho≈øe of the City, which acquired him a great Reputation.

Among the Painters that flouri≈øh'd at Venice at that time, Dominicus Venetianus was one of the mo≈øt celebrated; he very much care≈ø≈øed Antonelle at his Arrival, and thereby acquired his Friend≈øhip, in≈øomuch that he ≈øhew'd him the way of Painting in Oyl. After which Dominick in the Year 1478. carried this way of Painting in Oyl to Florence. He there made ≈øeveral Pieces
after this new way; but he was unfortunately A≈ø≈øa≈øinated by Andrew dal Ca≈øtagno, who became Jealous of his Knowledge, although he had learnt from him the way of Painting in Oyl. Thus Antonello and Dominick carried this way to Florence and Venice, and the way of doing it became known throughout all Italy, which was very advantageous to this Art, in bringing it to the Perfection it arrived to, in the Year 1400, and the whole Century 1500.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Painting was Re-e≈øtabli≈øh'd in ≈øeveral Provinces of Italy.

div.p: IN the other Provinces of Italy, as well as in Tu≈øcany, and the State of Venice, there were ≈øeveral Per≈øons at the ≈øame time apply'd them≈øelves to revive the Honour of the Arts of De≈øigning, but not in ≈øo great a number as at Florence, where their Genius's were naturally inclined to learn it; and who al≈øo had among them the advantage of an Academy of De≈øigning, which was in no other Cities. Thus we ≈øee that the Art began to come to Perfection not only at Venice, but al≈øo at Ferrara, at Mantua, and at Bulloign, where Francis Francia was of the fir≈øt Rank. Laurence Co≈øta of Ferrara, his Di≈øciple, made ≈øeveral of the fine≈øt Pieces that had yet ever appear'd there, although they were only painted in Di≈øtemper.

Co≈øta was very much honoured by Francis Gon≈øague, Marqui≈øs of Mantua, who cau≈øed him to Paint a Chamber in his Palace of St. Seba≈øtian: This Painter had ≈øeveral Pupils
Co≈øta had moreover for his Di≈øciples, Laurence Hercules da Ferrara, and Lewis Malino: Laurence had ≈øo great Friend≈øhip for his Ma≈øter that he did not leave him during his Life. He de≈øigned better than Co≈øta, as is apparent by the Pieces he made in the Chappel of St. Vincent, in the Church of St. Petronio at Bulloign: Do≈ø≈øo al≈øo learnt of Co≈øta, and excell'd particularly in making Landskips. Benvenuto Garofola, was al≈øo his Pupil, before he went to Study at Rome. , and it was he who taught the fir≈øt Principles of the Art to Old Do≈ø≈øo da Ferrara.

Andrew Mantegna learnt Painting about this time of James Squarcione
Be≈øides Andrew Mantegna, who was a Di≈øciple of Squarcione, Laurence da Lendinara, Dario da Trevi≈øa, and Marco Zoppo, a Bolonian, were his Di≈øciples al≈øo. Andrew Mantegne was Knighted, and dy'd at Mantua in the Year 1517. This was his Epitaph.
E≈ø≈øe Parem hunc noris, ≈øi non praeponis Apelli,
Aenea Mantin√©ae qui ≈øimulachra vides.
of Padua, who lived at Mantua: Andrew was very much e≈øteemed by Gonzagues, Marqui≈øs of that State: The Triumph which he painted in his Palace, of which there is to be ≈øeen a Print, gain'd him ≈øo much Reputation, that Pope Innocent the Eighth ≈øent for him to Rome, to Paint the Palace of Belvidere; and after having acquired a great deal of Honour at the Court of Rome, he returned to Mantua, where he ended his Days.

Gentil da
Gentil da Fabriano made ≈øome Pieces that were highly prai≈øed by Michael Angelo. Pi≈øanello, a Painter, of Verona, was Contemporary with Gentil, and he was very much e≈øteemed by Michael St. Michael, Architect of Verona; he excell'd al≈øo in graving Medals, which he made appear by tho≈øe he did at Florence, of all tho≈øe Illu≈øtrious Per≈øons, who a≈ø≈øi≈øted at the Council held there with the Grecians. Il Biondo and Il Giovio, very much extolled the Medals of Pi≈øanello.
In the ≈øame Age, 1400. there flouri≈øhed in Tu≈øcany, ≈øeveral Excellent Painters in Miniature, who were the Fryer John da Fie≈øole, Don Bartholomew, Abbot of St. Clement, and Gherardo.
Fabriano practi≈øed Painting at Verona, and taught it to James Bellini, who was contemporary with Dominick Venetianus; but when this la≈øt left Venice to dwell at Florence, there was no body left at Venice to di≈øpute with him the Precedency. He had two Children,
John Bellin made ≈øeveral Pieces at Venice, and lived 90 Years; he had al≈øo for his Di≈øciples, James da Montagna, Rondinello da Ravenna, Benedict Coda da Ferrara, and ≈øeveral others of Lombardy and Trevi≈øan; as for Gentil Bellin, he dy'd at 80 Years of Age. Vivarini was one of his Contemporaries, and he work'd with the Bellinis in one of the Halls of the Palaces of St. Mark, but he dy'd young.
Francis Mo≈øignori, a Verone≈øe, was Di≈øciple of Andrew Mantagna; he wrought at Mantua, where he made ≈øeveral Pieces; and at Verona he dy'd in the Year 1509.
John and Gentil, whom he taught to Paint; they ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed their Father in a little time, and we may truly ≈øay, it was the≈øe two Brothers who introduced the right Method of managing Colours in the Venetian School, after having brought up ≈øeveral Ingenious Di≈øciples, one whereof was the Famous Georgeone da Ca≈øtel-Franco.

The Reputation of the two Brothers, Bellini, encrea≈øing at Venice daily, by the great number of Pictures which they made, went even to Con≈øtantinople,
for the Republick made a Pre≈øent of their Works to Mahomet the II. who was ≈øo charmed therewith, that he ≈øent for the Painters who had done them.

The Senate immediately ≈øent Gentil Bellin, who at his Arrival at Con≈øtantinople, pre≈øented that Emperor with one of his Pictures, who ≈øo much admired it that he thought it impo≈ø≈øible for Man to Expre≈øs any thing ≈øo much to the Life.

This Great Prince not being able to keep Gentil any longer by rea≈øon of his Religion, which forbids Pictures, took his leave of this Famous Painter, heaping Honours upon him, as on a Per≈øon of the highe≈øt Reputation, offering him to grant him any thing he would demand of him. But Bellin only de≈øired a Letter of him to ≈øignify to the Republick the Satisfaction he had received in him, which this Sultan readily and joyfully con≈øented to; and Bellin
John Bellin, in his old Age, only drew Portraits, and introduc'd the Cu≈øtom among the Nobles of Venice to have their Pictures drawn, them and their Families, a Cu≈øtom very beneficial to the Painters. at his return gave it the Senate, who a≈ø≈øigned him a Pen≈øion during Life.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: The School of Florence became very Famous by the great number of Excellent Men it produced.

div.p:
As Painting became more perfect at Venice, by tho≈øe Ingenious Painters I have mentioned, ≈øo the Great
One of the greate≈øt Genius's in Painting of the Age, 1400. was Dominick Ghirlandaio, of whom we have made mention in the Fourth Chapter, which is evident by the great number of his Excellent Works. Nature gave him a very great Inclination for Painting, which was the rea≈øon he left off from his Youth following the Trade of a Gold≈ømith, wherein his Father had Educated him; he was the fir≈øt who invented that Dre≈øs which the Florentine-Maids wear on their Heads, called Ghirlande; whence he was named Dominick Ghirlandaio. As he ≈øucceeded in the true Methods of Painting, he imitated in his Colours the Ornaments of Gold, which till that time were done with real Gold. The Reputation of Dominick got to Rome, where Pope Sixtus the Fourth ≈øent for him to Paint in his Chappel; at his Return to Florence, he painted the Chappel of Ricci, which was one of the chief Pieces; he was u≈øed to ≈øay that De≈øigning was true Painting, and that Mo≈øaick was the mo≈øt durable; he dy'd at 44 Years of Age, in the Year 1493. His Di≈øciples were David and Benedict Chirlandaio, Seba≈øtian Maimardi, Michael-Angelo Buonarotti, and ≈øeveral other Ingenious Florentine-Ma≈øters.
At the ≈øame time Benedict da Maiano di≈øtingui≈øhed him≈øelf at Florence in Sculpture and Architecture, as did al≈øo Anthony and Peter Pollaivoli, Florentine Painters and Sculptors; they dy'd at Rome, whither Pope Innocent, the Succe≈ø≈øor of Sixtus the Fourth cau≈øed them to come; they were very Curious, and the fir≈øt, who ≈øtudied Anatomy, whereby they made their Works the more perfect.
There appeared al≈øo at Florence about this time, Philip Lippia, Painter, who fir≈øt taught to Paint varieties of Cloathing in his Figures, and therein imitated the Ancients; he had a great Genius in Ornaments and Grote≈øque, he wrought al≈øo in Plai≈øter; and died at 45 Years of Age. Moreover Luke Signorelli of Cortone, got Reputation by his Painting in that City, and in Arezzo; he had a fertil Invention, and a great deal of Grace in Compo≈øing his Hi≈øtories, and de≈øigned very well Naked-Figures.
Genius's in that Art continued daily to bring about the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the Arts of De≈øigning.

Among the re≈øt, the Illu≈øtrious Leonard da Vinci became a great Ma≈øter therein; for from his Birth he had all the Advantages of Nature, which procured him an ea≈øy Entrance into all the Arts that depend on De≈øigning, and Mathematicks, Mu≈øick, and Poetry, wherein he was Excellent.

Leonard learn'd of Andrew Verrocchio Painting and Sculpture, but in a ≈øhort time ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed his Ma≈øter in Painting; he ≈øtudied Per≈øpective, and the Arts that depend thereon, and penetrated into the mo≈øt hidden Secrets of Anatomy,
Leonard da Vinci, Michael Angelo, and all the be≈øt De≈øigners ≈øtudied Anatomy. Da Vinci carefully recommends that Study in his Treati≈øe of Painting, as does al≈øo Lomazzo in his. Charles Alphon≈øus of Fre≈ønoy, and D. P. his Commentator, have al≈øo ≈øhewed the nece≈ø≈øity of Myology to become Excellent in De≈øigning. The Author of the Di≈øcour≈øes on the Lives, and the Works of the mo≈øt Excellent Painters, is al≈øo of this Sentiment; but in treating of this Science, he explains him≈øelf in very confu≈øed terms, for he mi≈øtakes the Tendons for the Nerves; for in writing of the Statue of Laocoon, in a Conference, in the Academy, he expre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf thus, ≈øaying, The Nerves and Mu≈øcles form the chief Appearances of that Statue. And in his Book of Di≈øcour≈øes, ≈øpeaking of the Mu≈øcles, he teaches in Page 315. of P. T. That there mu≈øt be had a ≈øpecial regard to the Mu≈øcles and Nerves: And in Page 556. he ≈øays, That their Motions depend on the Fabrick of the Bones, and Situation of the Mu≈øcles and Tendons, which ≈øu≈øtain them, and cau≈øe their Action. In another place he ≈øays, As the Mu≈øcles and Nerves are more ≈øupple and pliant; which cau≈øes an Alteration in the Nerves, &c. It will not be ami≈øs, to Explain this for the ≈øake of young Beginners. To do this, you are to con≈øider Three Parts in each Mu≈øcle; the Head, the Belly, and the Tail, which are only their Beginning, Middle, and End; this end of the Mu≈øcle, is that which is called the Tendon, re≈øembling Cords, which the Author of the Di≈øcour≈øes calls Nerves, at the Feet of Laocoon; where it is evident, that they are the Tendons of the long and ≈øhort Enten≈øors of the Fingers, which end at the Articulations of each of them, being there very vi≈øible, by rea≈øon of the dolorous Motions, which Age≈øander, the Sculptor, ≈øhews this Figure to have made at the biting of ≈øeveral Serpents. As to what this Author ≈øays, That the Tendons ≈øu≈øtain the Mu≈øcles, and cau≈øe them to Act; this is to ≈øpeak without any under≈øtanding in Anatomy or De≈øign; he might have ≈øaid, That the Tendons end the Mu≈øcles, but not that they cau≈øe their Motion. For the Animal Spirits give Motion to the Mu≈øcles, which are communicated to them by the Nerves, which are their Vehicle; but the≈øe Nerves are diffu≈øed, and lo≈øe them≈øelves among the Membranes, and Fle≈øh, by ≈ømall Ramuli or Branches, which end like Hairs; ≈øo that they cannot be ≈øeen without the Skin; on the contrary, they are the Tendons that are there ≈øeen, which indeed the Ancient Language calls Nerves, when Anatomy was not arrived to that Perfection as now-a-days. This appears in an old Tran≈ølation of the Bible, Gen. 32.25. where the Angel after having wre≈øtled all Night with Jacob, not being able to overcome him, touched him on the Nerve of the Thigh, and immediately it dry'd and wither'd, and he became Lame (this Nerve is properly the Tendon of the Mu≈øcle, called the Biceps of the Thigh). In Memory of this Action, the Children of I≈ørael did not Eat in Animals this part, like the Tendon, which was withered in Jacob by the touch of the Angel of the Lord. Idem, Ver. 32. which evidentlv proves, that it is not only the Nerve, but the Tendon which makes part of the Mu≈øcle. and the Motion of the Mu≈øcles, by the Studies which he made under Mark Anthony de la Tour, Profe≈ø≈øor in that Science.

The Beauty of the Celebrated Leonardo, advanced his Reputation throughout all Italy, and beyond it, which made Lewis Sforza, Duke of Milan, ≈øend for him to come to him. The fir≈øt thing he ≈øet about, was to Re-e≈øtabli≈øh the Academy of Architecture, founded at Milan a hundred Years before, by Micheline. For he ≈øhewed the way to that A≈ø≈øembly to leave their old Gothick Manner. He made for this Prince ≈øeveral Pictures, and among the re≈øt, the admirable Supper of the Refectory of St. Dominick: He found out the Invention of making the Canal, which carries the Water from Adda to Milan, and to make that River navigable for thirty Miles beyond it.

But as Leonardo was always meditating on extraordinary Things, for the Glory of the Prince whom he ≈øerved, he made a Model in Earth of a Figure on Hor≈øeback, of a remarkable heigth, and ≈øingular Beauty, with a de≈øign to Ca≈øt it in Bra≈øs; but that was not done, whether for the difficulty of Founding ≈øo great a Work, or for ≈øome other Rea≈øon; and this fine Model was ruined when the French conquered the Milane≈øe.

After Lewis Sforza was carried into France, Leonardo returned to Florence, where he Painted ≈øeveral Pieces, and de≈øigned upon large thick Paper, like Pa≈øtboard, which Raphael al≈øo made u≈øe of, and thereon brought to Perfection the Method of Perrugin, his Ma≈øter. Julian de Medicis did no le≈øs Honour to Leonardo da Vinci, than the Duke of Milan. For, be≈øides the other Care≈ø≈øes he ≈øhew'd him, he carried him to Rome to the Election of Leo the Tenth, and he receiv'd of this Pope the like Honour; but the Jealou≈øy between
him and Michael Angelo di≈øpleas'd the Court of Rome, and obliged him to go into France, where Francis the I. had pa≈ø≈øionately de≈øired his Company, for the E≈øteem he had for his Per≈øon, and Pictures, which hung up in his Clo≈øet at Fontainbleau.

In this Royal Hou≈øe this Painter grew Aged, and made an Illu≈øtrious End; for after he had received much Honour and great Riches from this Generous Prince, he fell Sick; and when his Maje≈øty was adverti≈øed of it, he went to Vi≈øit him. Da Vinci would needs rai≈øe him≈øelf up to receive ≈øo glorious a Vi≈øit; whereon finding him≈øelf extream Ill, the King approaching him Embrac'd him, and he Expired
Leonardo da Vinci died at the Age of 75 Years; be≈øides his Treati≈øe of Painting, which is Printed, he compo≈øed ≈øeveral other Books; one of the Anatomy of Human Bodies with Figures; one of the Anatomy of an Hor≈øe; another of Lights and Shadows; and one of the Nature, Weight, and Motion of the Water, filled with De≈øigns of Machines; but unfortunately they were never Printed. John Bapti≈øta Strozzi has left us the≈øe Ver≈øes in his prai≈øe:
Vinci co≈øtui pur ≈øolo
Tutti altri: & Vince Fidia, & vince apelle:
Et tutto il lor vittorio≈øo Stuolo.
He had for his Pupils, John Antony Boltraffo, a Milane≈øe; Francis Melzi of the ≈øame City; and ≈øome hold that Andrew de Solario was al≈øo his Pupil. in his Arms.

This Great Monarch loved Learning and Arts, with ≈øo much Pa≈ø≈øion, that he e≈øteem'd it a Glory to Paint and De≈øign; and it may be ≈øaid, That this King revived Painting, and Sculpture, and Architecture. For he was not contented to ≈øend for Leonardo da Vinci only, but he drew from
Florence a great number of Ingenious Men, as Andrew
Andrew del Sarto was Born at Florence in 1478. he learnt the Trade of a Gold≈ømith; then he took to Painting under Peter Co≈øimo, who was then e≈øteemed to be one of the be≈øt Painters in Florence. He ≈øtudied al≈øo in the Council-Hall, the Pieces done by Leonardo da Vinci and Michael Angelo, and made ≈øeveral admirable Pieces at Florence, as the Cloy≈øter of the Annunziata, la Madonna del Sacco, and ≈øeveral others, which gain'd him a very great Reputation. His Di≈øciples were James de Puntormo Solo≈ømeo, F. Franci≈øo di Sandro, Francis Salviati, George Va≈øari, and Andrew Sguazzella, who very much imitated him; he work'd in a Palace a little without Paris, as al≈øo did the ≈øaid Va≈øari; and it is very probable, that it was from hence that tho≈øe Pictures were carried to Paris, which are in the great Gallery of the Je≈øuits, which have the Way of De≈øigning, and Method of Andrew del Sarto. Andrew lived forty two Years. M. Peter Vettori made this Epitaph on Andrew del Sarto.
Admirabilis ingenii Pictori, ac Veteribus illis omnium judicio comparando,
Dominicus Contes di≈øcipulus, pro laboribus, in ≈øe in≈øtituendo ≈øu≈øceptis, grato Animo po≈øuit.
