del Sarto, Ro≈ø≈øo, Dominick the Florentine, Salviati, and ≈øeveral other Excellent Painters, and Excellent Sculptors; as he did al≈øo from Mantua, Primaticcio, a Bolonian, and Nicholas of Modena, all of whom work'd in, and embelli≈øh'd the Royal Hou≈øes, and ≈øtirr'd up the French to Emulation, which made them very much improve in the Art of De≈øigning.

Among the≈øe Illu≈øtrious Italians, Andrew del Sarto held the fir≈øt Rank in the Florentine-School, for the Correctne≈øs of his De≈øigning, and becau≈øe he had rai≈øed Painting to his highe≈øt Degree of Perfection.

Peter Perugino
Peter Perugino dy'd at 78 Years of Age, in the Year 1524. Be≈øides his Di≈øciple Raphael, he had ≈øeveral other very ingenious ones, as Pinturicchio Perugino, Rocco Zoppo, a Florentine, Philip Salviati, Le Monte Varchi, Baccio Ubertino, a Florentine, Peter John, a Spaniard; but one of his be≈øt, was Andrew Lewis d'A≈øce≈øi, and Benedict Caporali, who al≈øo gave him≈øelf to Architecture, and made Comments on Vitruvius. had the ≈øame advantage at Florence, and at Rome, where he made ≈øeveral Excellent Pieces, and particularly in the Chappel of Sixtus the Fourth.
But that which augmented the Glory of this Ingenious Painter, was, that he had for his fir≈øt Di≈øciple, Raphel Sanzio d'Urbin.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

p.hi: Of the Perfection of Painting in the la≈øt Age.

div.p:
IT was Raphael d'Urbin, who rai≈øed Painting in the la≈øt Age to its highe≈øt degree of Perfection: His Works which are at Rome, at Florence, at Bologna
At Bologna in the Church of St. John on the Hill are ≈øome admirable Pieces of Raphael, which repre≈øent St. Cecilia with other Saints. Raphael, when he had fini≈øhed this Picture, ≈øent it to Francis Francia a Painter of Bologna, praying him to take care to ≈øet it up at the Altar he had di≈øign'd it for; Francia who believ'd him≈øelf to be a better Painter than in reality he was, and who had a great De≈øire to ≈øee the Works of Raphael, whom he only knew by Fame, and by the great Reputation he had gotten, was glad of this Occa≈øion, but he had no ≈øooner taken the Picture out of its Ca≈øe, but he was ≈øo ≈øurprized at its Excellence, and thereupon conceived ≈øuch a Melancholy by finding him≈øelf ≈øo much Inferiour to Raphael, that he fell Sick and in a few days dyed. Va≈øari, Vita de Pitt. &c. Francis Francia was born in the Year 1450; he was brought up a Gold≈ømith, wherein he excell'd in working in Enamel, and graving of Coins for Money; his Medals equall'd tho≈øe of Carado≈ø≈øe, as is to be ≈øeen by tho≈øe of Pope Julius the IId. of the Seignior Benti-Voglio, and by all the Coins of the Money of Bologna which he cut as long as he lived. He took up Painting after he was acquainted with Andrew Mantegna; he was the fir≈øt Painter of Bologna, and excelled all the Bolognians that went before him; his School was ≈øo Famous that by relation of Malva≈øia, he had brought up two hundred Di≈øciples; one of the be≈øt who learned of Francia was Laurence Co≈øta, whereof we have ≈øpoken in the VIIth Chap. Malva≈øia Vite de' Pitt.
This Author denies what Va≈øari relates of the Death of Francia, becau≈øe this Painter had ≈øeen other Pictures of Raphael, before he received that of St. Cecilia; and had te≈øtified to Raphael in Letters that pa≈ø≈øed between them, the E≈øteem he had for him, as the Painter of Painters; which he takes notice of in the≈øe Words, che tu ≈øolo il pittor ≈øei de' pittori.
Malva≈øia moreover complains of Va≈øari, That he would not own that there were Painters at Bologna at lea≈øt as ≈øoon as at Florence, for he ≈øays, that in the Year 1115 to 1140 there appear'd at Bologna Guido, Ventura and Or≈øon, who embelli≈øh'd with Pictures the Churches of La Madonna de Lambertazzi, of St. E≈øtienne, and ≈øeveral others of that City. Afterwards appeared Marin the Gold≈ømith and Engraver, and Franco de Bologna Painter, contemporary of Giotto, who notwith≈øtanding follow'd the Gothick Way; in the mean time they were very much prai≈øed by Dante: Franco work'd for Pope Benedict the IXth, in the Vatican. It was he who ≈øet up the fir≈øt School of Painting at Bologna, and brought up ≈øeveral Pupils, and among the re≈øt Simon, Jacob de Avanzi, and Vitale who ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed him. This la≈øt flouri≈øhed about the Year 1345, and the others in 1370. At fir≈øt Simon only painted Crucifix's, whence he got the Name of Simon of the Crucifix; and as for Jacob he only drew Pictures of the Virgin: Their Works have been prai≈øed by Michael Angelo and the Characci.
At the ≈øame time appeared Galeazzo of Ferrara and Chri≈øto≈øano da Modena, the≈øe Painters wrought in the Church called La Ca≈øe di Mezzo, without the Gate Mammola: And all their Works appear'd in the Year 1400. Jacob moreover work'd with Aldigieri de Levio a Famous Painter. Lippo Dalma≈øio was Di≈øciple of Vitale and taught Painting to M. Galante the Bolognians This Lippo as Malva≈øia pretends painted in Oyl. From the Year 1400. Painting grew more and more to Perfection at Bologna by Mattheo; one of his mo≈øt famous Pieces was at St. Francis, which he painted in Oyl in 1443 under the little Gate of the Fi≈øhery. Afterwards Severus of Bologna wrought in 1460. James Ripenda painted ≈øeveral Pieces at Rome, and De≈øigned the whole Trajan Column; there were at that time ≈øeveral very good Bolognian Painters, whereof Marco Zoppo was One, his Works appear'd about the End of the Age 1400, he was Di≈øciple of Squarcione: But his greate≈øt Glory was to have brought up Francis Francia who revived Painting at Bologna, from the low E≈øtate whereunto it was fallen, and introduced the true Method and Gu≈øto of De≈øigning and Painting as we have ≈øhewn. and in France are illu≈øtrious Proofs of it, and give Subject both for our Admiration and Study.

This rare Per≈øon had a very happy Genius, and from his Infancy a great Inclination for Painting: He learn'd the Principles from his Father, in the City of Urbin, which was his Native Country: But his Father ≈øeeing that from his Youth he exceeded him, put him to Peter Perugino one of the mo≈øt renowned Painters of Florence: Whom Raphael in a ≈øhort time ≈øo well imitated, that oftentimes the Work of this Di≈øciple ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed that of his Ma≈øter. After Raphael had left Perugino, he travelled to Siena, where he heard of the great E≈øteem that was made at Florence, of a Piece whereon was de≈øigned a Battel which the Famous Leonard da Vinci made for the Council Hall. He under≈øtood al≈øo that there was another Piece of De≈øigning very much admired, which Michael Angelo had done in the ≈øame Hall, where Leonard and Michael Angelo had painted each one half. This obliged Raphael to leave his Work to go to Florence to ≈øee the≈øe two Famous Pieces: Which he had no ≈øooner ≈øeen, but he bethought him≈øelf that he mu≈øt ≈øtudy hard to acquire tho≈øe Excellences in De≈øigning, wherein he then acknowledged him≈øelf inferiour to tho≈øe two Ingenious Painters.

Thus he ≈øtudied very hard to acquire the true Idea of tho≈øe fine Airs of the Head, that roundne≈øs, force and perfection of the Works of Leonard: he al≈øo ob≈øerved the Beautiful outlines of the naked Figures, in the De≈øigns of Michael Angelo, and that that Beauty and Correctne≈øs proceeded from the true Proportion, and natural Situation of the Mu≈øcles, and the ju≈øt ob≈øervation of their Motions; Raphael that he might acquire this Knowledge, ≈øet him≈øelf diligently to ≈øtudy Anatomy, and his whole De≈øign was to quit the
manner of his Ma≈øter Peter Perugino, wherein he happily ≈øucceeded: For it was generally more petite, a dryer, and a harder manner than that of Leonardo, or Michael Angelo.

This Method of Perugino had not that roundne≈øs nor true Gu≈øto as the Pieces of Fr√† Bartholomew
Bartholomew, according to the Language of that Country called Baccio, began to learn Painting under Benedict de Maiano, and afterwards under Co≈øimo Ro≈ø≈øelli, and at la≈øt he ≈øet him≈øelf to Study the Works and Method of Leonard da Vinci‚ñ™ He was per≈øwaded by the Famous Jerom Savonarola, a Dominican, to quit Temporal Affairs, and to burn all his Works and De≈øigns, among which were ≈øeveral naked Figures, and by a Vow became one of that Religious Order, in the Convent of St. Mark at Florence; whence he was ≈øince named Fr√† Bartholomew, of St. Mark; he dyed at the Age of 40 Years in 1517; his Di≈øciples were Cechino del Frate: Benedictus Ciamfanini, Gabriel Ru≈øtici and Fr√† Paolo Pi≈øtole≈øe. , of St. Mark, one of the Imitators of Leomard. Bartholomew by help of his Studies, and the great E≈øteem he had for the Works of that Excellent Man, arrived to that degree of Perfection in true De≈øigning, that he was one of the mo≈øt Excellent Painters of his Time. Several Pictures which are at Florence and at Lucca, in the Churches of St. Martin and St. Romanus are illu≈øtrious Proofs it: They appear to this Day as fre≈øh as if they were newly painted: For be≈øides the Beauty of their De≈øigning they had a very fine Colour, and a wonderful Relief cau≈øed by a ju≈øt di≈øtribution of Light and a grand Force of Shadow, with an admirable Union and Perfection.

The Beauty of the≈øe excellent Pieces very much charmed Raphael at Florence, and obliged him to contract an intimate Friend≈øhip with Bartholomew, from whom he learn'd with a great deal of Care
and Advantage the way of Painting and Colouring: The Friend≈øhip of Raphael was al≈øo no ways di≈øadvantageous to Fr√† Bartholomew, for Raphael communicated to him the Rules of Per≈øpective, which he was not before ≈øo well acquainted with as he.

Thus Raphael Sanzio, joining to the Gifts Heaven had favoured him with, all the care and different Studies that were nece≈ø≈øary, formed that fine Method of his, which ≈øhines through all his rich and judicious Compo≈øitions. His Po≈øtures are ea≈øy, natural and lively in each Expre≈ø≈øion, his Proportions elegant and taken from the fine Figures of the Antients, all the Airs of his Faces ≈øo noble that they ≈øeemed to have ≈øomething of Divine in them; in ≈øhort, he fini≈øh'd all the Extremities of his Figures with the utmo≈øt Perfection, and had the truly fine Way of cloathing them; the≈øe are tho≈øe excellent Parts of the Art which make his Pictures the mo≈øt perfect among the Moderns, which this great Painter has made appear in the Palace of the Vatican, in all the Halls, and all the Lodges which he painted.

This is particularly to be ≈øeen in his Piece of the Transfiguration at St. Peters, in Montorio, which has always been e≈øteemed as one of the chief Pieces of Painting, and be≈øt Pictures in the World. Tho≈øe al≈øo which Francis the I. cau≈øed him to make in Oyl, and which are carefully pre≈øerved in the Cabinet of the King, ≈øufficiently te≈øtify this Truth.

This Piece of the Transfiguration was al≈øo the chief Ornament of his Funeral Pomp, which redoubled the publick Sorrow, when they ≈øaw that admirable Picture, near the Body of that rare Per≈øon, and that Death had ≈øo ≈øoon deprived that
Excellent Painter of Life, who will always live in the memory of the Lovers of this Art.

By this it is ea≈øy to judge that Raphael, was the mo≈øt excellent Genius in this ART, of the la≈øt Age, and that he carried it to its highe≈øt Perfection. But we may al≈øo ≈øay, that this admirable Man was Happy to flouri≈øh under the Popedoms of Julius the IId. and Leo the Xth. Princes very zealous for the revival of the Arts of De≈øigning. For this la≈øt Pope loved Raphael with ≈øuch an Affection, that at the time this Excellent Painter dyed, this Generous Pope had propo≈øed to Honour him with a Cardinals Hat
M. E≈øprit Flechier Bi≈øhop of Ni≈ømes, relates this of Raphael in his Hi≈øtory of Cardinal Ximenes Tome 2. P. 187.
Raphael made Julius Romanus, and John Francis his Heirs who were his Pupils; he dyed at the Age of 37 Years, and was buried in the Rotunda, where Bembo made his Epitaph, D. O. M.
Raphaeli Santio Joan. F. Verbinat. Pictori Eminenti≈øs. Veterum
que Emulo, cujus ≈øpirantes prope Imagines ≈øi contemplere, Naturae at
que Artis foedus facile impexeris. Julii II. & Leonis X. Pont. Max. Picturae, & Architect. Operibus gloriam auxit A. XXXVII. integer integros, Quo die natus e≈øt, eo e≈ø≈øe de≈øiit VIII Id. April. M. D. XX.
Ille e≈øt hic Raphael, timuit quo ≈øo≈øpite vinci
Rerum magna Parens, & moriente mori.
, and the≈øe Hopes hindred Raphael from concluding a Marriage with the Neice of Cardinal de Bibbiena, who de≈øired it with a great deal of Zeal.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: Of the Painters of Lombardy who contributed to the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the ART.

div.p: AT the ≈øame time that Raphael and his School revived Painting at Rome, the ingenious Arti≈øts of Lombardy In Lombardy, and the Provinces of the State of Venice, there were ≈øeveral Contemporary Painters, Di≈øciples of the Bellini, who contributed to the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of Painting in ≈øeveral Cities, although we only con≈øider them as of the ≈øecond Cla≈ø≈øe, and the≈øe are the Do≈ø≈øi of Ferrara, Sebeto of the ≈øame City, Jacobello de Florus, Guerriero of Padua, Ju≈øtus and Jerom Campagnola, Julius his Son, Vincent de Bre≈ø≈øe, Lewis Vivarino, John Bapti≈øta de Corrigliano, Mark Ba≈øarini, Giovannetto Cordeliaghi, Ba≈ø≈øiti, Bartelemi Vivarino, John Man≈øueti, Victor Bellin, Bartelemi Montagne de Vincenze, Benedictus Diada, John Boncon≈øil and Victor Scarpaccio who was the be≈øt of them all. There were al≈øo in tho≈øe Countries at the ≈øame time ≈øeveral Good Sculptors, as Bartelemi de Regge and Augu≈øtin Bu≈øto. There was al≈øo at Bre≈ø≈øe, Vincent Verochio who was Excellent at Painting in Fre≈øco; there was al≈øo in the ≈øame City Jerom Romanino, a good De≈øigner and ingenious Arti≈øt; but the mo≈øt Excellent of tho≈øe Painters at Bre≈ø≈øe was Alexander Moretto. But to return to Verona, there were very Good Painters, for, befides Mae≈øtro Zeno a Verone≈øe, Liberale was very Excellent, who was a Di≈øciple of E≈øtienne Verone≈øe, who had al≈øo others, as John Francis Caroto of the ≈øame City, Paul Cavazzuol and Francis Torbido, al≈øo Bapti≈øta de Angelo his Nephew. Moro learnt from his Youth of Georgeon, and whom he left an Account of a Quarrel they had at Venice, and retired to Verona, where for ≈øome time he left Painting, and afterwards took it up again in the School of Liberale. no le≈øs contributed towards it in their Country: So that we may look upon the beginning of the la≈øt Age, as the happy Time wherein the Arts of De≈øigning arrived in Italy to their highe≈øt Perfection.

For about that time, Antony
Antony da Correggio was he who brought Painting in Lombardy to its hige≈øt degree of Perfection; he made two Pictures for Duke Frederick of Mantua, which he ≈øent to the Emperor; when Julius Romanus ≈øaw them, he confe≈ø≈øed that no body had advanced Painting and Colouring to ≈øo high an Excellence before.
The≈øe two Pictures were carried to Rome by Queen Chri≈øtina, one whereof is a Leda with other Women bathing them≈øelves, which are of an incomparable Beauty and Perfection, as are al≈øo tho≈øe in the Kings Cabinet painted both in Oyl and water Colours. Correggio received at Parma a payment of ≈øixty Crowns in Quatrini (Money of Copper,) by carrying of which he ≈øo over-heated him≈øelf that he dyed at the Age of 40 Years; he made his Chief Pieces about the Year 1512.
M. Fabio Segni a Florentine Gentleman made this Epigram on him:
Hujus cum regeret mortales Spiritus artus
Pictoris, Charites ≈øupplicuere Jovi.
Non ali√¢ pingi dextr√¢ Pater alme rogamus,
Hanc praeter; nulli pingere nos liceat.
Annuit his votis ≈øummi regnator Olympi
Et juvenem ≈øubit√≤ ≈øidera ad alta tulit.
Ut po≈ø≈øet melius Charitum ≈øimulacra re≈øerre
Prae≈øens, & nudas cerneret inde Deas.
da Correggio by a particular In≈øtinct of Nature, without having any Ma≈øter, acquired a very agreeable and charming Way of Painting. This ingenious Man may be well termed the fir≈øt Painter of Lombardy, although the cour≈øe of his Life was but ≈øhort, and his Merits not ≈øufficiently known to tho≈øe who employ'd him: Notwith≈øtanding his excellent Works had the happine≈øs of being E≈øteem'd as Patterns of the fine≈øt Way of Painting, and to have ≈øhewed the true Reli≈øh and Perfection of the Art to Baroche, to Procaccino and the Famous Caraches, who all zealou≈øly imitated him, and particularly Studied his Works: E≈øpecially tho≈øe which
made the City of Parma ≈øo Famous, as the Paintings in Oyl of this Illu≈øtrious Painter, which are in the Churches of St. Anthony, St. John and St. Francis, and in other Places: But Hannibal Caracche ≈øet him≈øelf to ≈øtudy the fine≈øt Ways, the fine Airs of the Head, the Roundne≈øs, and the Relief which are very ≈øurprizing in tho≈øe admirable Stroaks, which Correggio painted in Fre≈øco, in that City in the Churches of the Cathedral and of St. John. It was from the≈øe fine Pieces that the Chevalier Lanfranc, took his Idea, in that fine Piece he did at Rome, in the Church of St. Andrew de Laval, and in others that he painted at Naples; for Le Corregio was the fir≈øt of the Painters who made that Sort of Pieces in Fre≈øco: And of ≈øuch a ≈øurprizing De≈øign, that the Figures ≈øeem'd ≈øtreight and upright contrary to the Nature of the concave Superficies of the Vault, and tho≈øe excellent Pieces ≈øerve ≈øtill for Patterns to tho≈øe who ≈øtudy the ≈øame Sorts of Work.

We may al≈øo rank among the famous Painters of Lombardy, Francis Mazzuolo
Parmeggiano was a very hand≈øom Man, of a very fine Air, and looked more like an Angel than a mortal Creature. Parmeggiano after he went from Rome gave him≈øelf to Alchymy, and made ≈øeveral tryals to ≈øix Mercury, which depriv'd us of the re≈øt of his Works.
Be≈øides Parmeggiano, the City of Parma furni≈øh'd us with ≈øeveral other Good Painters, as Michael Angelo An≈øelmi, who made a Piece after a Carton of Julio Romano in the Church of Notre-Dame della Stoccha, and made there ≈øeveral other Pictures. Jerom Mazzuolo Cou≈øin of Parmeggiano gained al≈øo a great Reputation.
Polidore as well as ≈øeveral other Ingenious Men left Rome when the Imperiali≈øts came to Be≈øiege it; he went to Naples where he painted ≈øome Fronts of Palaces, and ≈øome Pictures in Oyl: Afterwards he went to Me≈ø≈øina, where he made ≈øeveral Pieces in Fre≈øco and in Oyl, and as he was about to return to Rome again, he was a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinated in his Bed by his Servant who robbed him in the Year 1543. call'd Parmeggiano,
and Polidore Caravaggio: The Beauties which are to be ≈øeen in the Pictures of the fir≈øt, Surprize at fir≈øt Sight of the beholders; which was cau≈øed by his agreeable Way of Painting.

He had ≈øo happy a Genius, that at the Age of ≈øixteen Years he made of his own head ≈øeveral fine Pictures at Parma, and in the State of Mantua, where he work'd till he was nineteen Years of Age, and then he went to Rome; the Reputation of the Works of Raphael, and of Michael Angelo drew him thither: He carried along with him three little Pictures, and his own Portrait; which were no ≈øooner ≈øeen by Cardinal Datary, but he was introduced to Pope Clement the VIIth. who was charmed with the Beauty of his Pictures. Parmeggiano by this means got into the Service of the Pope, for whom he made ≈øeveral Pieces, and, during the time he was at Rome he ≈øo much ≈øtudied the Paintings of Raphael, that People u≈øed to ≈øay of him, that the Spirit of that great Painter was transfu≈øed into Parmeggiano.

This young Painter had ≈øuch a Love, and ≈øo a≈ø≈øiduous an Application to his Art, that being at Rome when it was Sacked by the Imperiali≈øts in 1527, and ≈øome Soldiers entring into his Chamber when he was at Work, he was not at all concerned, and ≈øo he was taken and ≈øet to be ran≈øomed: And bought him≈øelf off by ≈øome of his Pictures, being happily fallen into the Hands of a German Captain who was a great lover of De≈øigning; but he was no ≈øooner at Liberty, but he was taken again by other Soldiers, who robbed him of all he had. This misfortune cau≈øed his Return into Lombardy, where in 1548, he dyed at thirty ≈øix Years of Age.

Polidore da Carravaggio learned Painting in the School of Raphael, and perfected him≈øelf by a through Study of the Antients: His Painting is very Admirable, ≈øo well mixed with Lights and Shadows, that it made him pa≈øs in that Point for the be≈øt Painter that ever was. The Art of De≈øigning is very much indebted to him for his rich Inventions of Trophies, Ve≈ø≈øels and other Ornaments which he left to Po≈øterity.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: Painting, in Point of Colours, was brought to its greate≈øt Beauty at Venice.

div.p: THE School of the Bellini having, as we have ≈øeen, begun to revive the true Gu≈øt of Painting; their famous Di≈øciples Georgeone and Titian, did much exceed them; for they were acknowledged, as they yet are, by all Painters, for the greate≈øt Ma≈øters in the Arts of Colouring, and making Landskips, that ever were.

Georgeone
George del Ca≈øtel Franco was ≈øurnamed Georgeon by rea≈øon of his fine A≈øpect. del Ca≈øtel Franco was brought up at Venice; he learn'd to play on the Lute to admiration, and having al≈øo a good Voice, he became an Excellent Mu≈øician. He al≈øo apply'd him≈øelf there to Painting, where after having in a ≈øhort time learnt the Way of the Bellini, he ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed them, by rea≈øon of the vivacity of his Genius, and his ≈øtrong Inclination to Painting, and his
Studies on the Pieces of Leonardo da Vinci, whom he happily imitated in the force and ≈øweetne≈øs of his Manner. It was by the≈øe means that Georgeone attain'd to the true Way of Painting and Colouring, for which he was fam'd at Venice and in Trevi≈øan, and for the Pieces in Fre≈øco which he there painted, and for the Pieces in Oyl of the Portraitures of the greate≈øt Captains, as that of the Prince Ga≈øton de Foix which is to be ≈øeen in the Kings Cabinet.

He al≈øo gave proofs of his Wit and Knowledge in a Di≈øpute he had at Venice with ≈øome Sculptors, concerning the Preeminence they pretended to over the Painters, becau≈øe Sculpture repre≈øents all the Parts of the Body, whereas Painting repre≈øents only one: But he ≈øhew'd them the contrary of this in one of his Pictures, wherein he ≈øhewed four different Sights or Parts of a Figure. To do this he painted a naked Man who ≈øhewed his Shoulders, and on the Ground he repre≈øented a Fountain where were to be ≈øeen by Reflexion the The Reflexions of Objects from poli≈øh'd and ≈øhining Bodies, as well as from Diaphanous ones, like the Water, are very agreeable in Pictures, when made by the Rules of Diopticks, as is done by the Illu≈øtrious Pou≈ø≈øin, who in that as well as ≈øome other Parts of Painting has exceeded all other Painters. The Author of the Di≈øcour≈øes, &c. witne≈ø≈øeth this, and blames Painters for neglecting the Study of them. He gives us in that Part of his Book the Rea≈øon of tho≈øe Sorts of Reflexions by a Geometrical demon≈øtration on a Landskip he Engraved; whereon is repre≈øented a Terras Walk and a Pillar thereon on the Bank of a River, where they are reflected: But for this Landskip he did not chu≈øe a good De≈øigner, for on the Water he ≈øhews Places beyond the Column over the top of it, where there could only be the Reflexion of the Terras; wherefore this Example ought not to be taken for a Pattern; in the mean while it is ea≈øy to find the Practice of repre≈øenting the≈øe Reflections: It is only nece≈ø≈øary to take the Heigth of the Objects on the River's Bank, and lay them down perpendicularly in a right line forwards to the place where the extremity of the Object reflected would come. But to find the Reflexion of tho≈øe that are di≈øtant from the Bank of the River, you mu≈øt prolong the Surface to the Plan of the Elevation of the Bodies, and ≈øo take the Heigth of this Plan found or imagined, and turn it perpendicularly forwards, then its extremity will be the term of the Reflexion of the Object that appears on the Water. In the explication of the principal Terms of Painting, we will give a more ample Demon≈øtration of this in Figures. Fore-parts of the Figure. On one of
the ≈øides he made a Suit of poli≈øh'd Armor whence one of the Sides was reflected, and on the other ≈øide there was ≈øeen a Looking-Gla≈øs which reflected the other: And after this way Georgeone repre≈øented at one View tho≈øe different A≈øpects; and this Picture was e≈øteemed one of the be≈øt of his Painting. This excellent Per≈øon dyed at the Age of thirty four Years of the Plague in 1511, with this further Encomium, that he had taught the true Way of Painting to Titian and Seba≈øtian, afterwards called Frate del Piombo.

Titian Vecellio of Cadora was born in 1477, he came to Venice at ten Years of Age, where he gave the fir≈øt hints of his Inclination to Painting; his Friends put him to John Bellino, where he pre≈øently di≈øcovered an excellent Genius for learning all the Arts nece≈ø≈øary and requi≈øite to Painting. But in the Year 1507, finding that the Method of Georgeone ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed that of Bellino, he imitated Georgeone with a great deal of care, and became his Di≈øciple, and even exceeded him, for he became the mo≈øt famous Colourer of his Time: As all Painters have ≈øince acknowledged.

This obliged Michael Angelo to ≈øay when he knew Titian at Rome, That if at the beginning of his Studies, he had been as happy as the Florentines, and the Romans, to have had as well as they the Antiquities to have learned by, he would been the fir≈øt Painter in the World.

Notwith≈øtanding Titian De≈øigned the be≈øt of any of the Venetian School; he particularly excelled in De≈øign tho≈øe of the la≈øt Age, and this appear'd in his Picture of Loves which was at Rome, in the Ludovi≈øian Vineyard: For the Illu≈øtrious Pou≈ø≈øin ≈øtudied afterwards with the Famous Sculptor Francis Fiamingo, who made the Cupids in that Piece, and who by this means learned thereby the true Gu≈øto and way of making Infants, whereby he got ≈øo great an E≈øteem for Sculpture.

Moreover this great Reputation of Titian
The Merit of Titian was ≈øo much valued by Charles the Vth, that he honoured him with the Dignity of a Knight and Count Palatine, and gave him ≈øeveral Marks of his E≈øteem; One day as the Emperor was ≈øeeing him Paint, Titian let fall his Pencil, the Emperor immediately took it up, ≈øaying, that Titian de≈øerved to be ≈øerved by Cae≈øar; and the Grandees of the Court being jealous of the Honours the Emperor heaped on him, the Emperor ≈øaid He could every Day make Great Men, as they were, but he could not make a Titian. As often as he painted this Great Prince, he received a Pre≈øent of a thou≈øand Growns of Gold. Among the re≈øt of the Princes of Europe who≈øe Portraits he drew, he did that of Francis the I≈øt, which is ≈øtill in the Cabinet of the King at Ver≈øailles, and appears very lively.
Titian moreover began the De≈øigns of ≈øeveral Pieces in Mo≈øaick in the Church of St. Mark, which were fini≈øhed by Valerius and Vincent Zuccheri, the be≈øt Arti≈øts of tho≈øe Times. Titian dyed of the Plague in the Year 1576, Aged 99 Years.
Several Painters endeavoured to follow the Manner of Colouring of Titian; but he had but few Di≈øciples, becau≈øe he did not care to take the Pains of In≈øtructing them: Among tho≈øe he did Teach, the mo≈øt Ingenious were John de Calker, who lived not long, and dyed at Naples, and Paris Bordone of Trevi≈øano, who imitated Titian the be≈øt of any. He made ≈øome excellent Pieces in Oyl, and in Fre≈øco at Venice, at Vicenza, and at Trevis, with ≈øeveral fine Portraits and Pictures in the Churches: He came into France and ≈øerved Francis the I≈øt, who≈øe Portrait he made, as al≈øo tho≈øe of the han≈øome≈øt Ladies at the Court, and ≈øeveral Pieces of Hi≈øtory. He al≈øo work'd for the Princes of the Hou≈øe of Lorrain; then he went and painted at Ausburg and Milan, whence he retired into his Country, and only work'd for his Plea≈øure, and lived very happily to the Age of 75 Years, and then dyed.
John Marius Verdizzoti, an illu≈øtrious Citizen of Venice, was a great Intimate of Titian, and ought to be reckoned among his Di≈øciples, ≈øince he learn'd of him to Paint. There are Engraven ≈øome De≈øigns of Verdizzoti, which are E≈øop's Fables, very curiou≈øly done. made him ≈øought to by all the Princes of Europe, to draw their Pictures, of whom he obtain'd great Honours and large Pen≈øions: Tho≈øe which he obtained from Charles the Vth, and Philip the IId, ≈øufficiently te≈øtify the E≈øteem they made of his Merit in Italy, Germany and Spain, where he gloriou≈øly embelli≈øh'd the E≈øcurial, as he had done other famous Cabinets of Europe.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: The ≈øame Curio≈øity was in all the Courts of Europe, and chiefly in that of Mantua.

div.p: BY the Examples of all tho≈øe great Men we have but now mentioned, it is evident, that this Curio≈øity had got among the Great Princes of the la≈øt Age, who gave Proofs even to Emulation of their endeavours to Revive the Arts of De≈øigning. Thus Painting and Architecture made great Progre≈ø≈øes by the Protection they found from the Princes, and the Ingenuity of tho≈øe Excellent Per≈øons who Cultivated them.

At this time the≈øe Arts continued to flouri≈øh at Mantua; for after De≈øigning had begun to be e≈øtabli≈øhed there by the Curio≈øity of tho≈øe Marqui≈øs's and Dukes, who employ'd Leon Bapti≈øta Alberti Co≈øta, and Andrew Mantegna, the famous Julio Romano made that City very fine.

Thus, when this Illu≈øtrious De≈øigner had fini≈øh'd Painting Con≈øtantine's Hall at Rome, which Raphael, his Ma≈øter, was to have done; Frederick, Duke of Mantua, went thither, where he was ≈øo charm'd with Julio, that he oblig'd him to leave Rome, and come to Mantua.

He there immediately ordered him to Build the Palace of T. whereof he afterwards painted all the Apartments; and it was in the≈øe Magnificent Works, that he ≈øhew'd the Greatne≈øs and Vivacity of his Genius; there is to be ≈øeen on the four ≈øides of the Hall, which is painted in Fre≈øco, the Overthrow of the Giants; and on
the Cieling, Jupiter darting his Thunderbolts; as al≈øo all the re≈øt of the Gods amazed at their Boldne≈øs. Julio, moreover, painted the Loggia or Gallery of this Palace, where are the Hi≈øtories of David; and al≈øo Embelli≈øh'd the Great Hall with the Fables of P≈øyche and Bacchus. He adorn'd ≈øeveral other Apartments with Pictures and Stucco-work, which were all very admirable.

He painted, moreover, ≈øeveral Battels out of Homer's Iliads in the Palace of St. Seba≈øtian, and made fine Pieces of Tapi≈øtry for the Duke of Ferrara, which repre≈øented the Combats and Triumph of Scipio Africanus, whereof the King, the Duke of Mantua, and the Duke of Modena; have each a Suit of Hangings, very richly highten'd with Gold The≈øe Tapi≈øtries were made in Flanders by Nicholas and John Bapti≈øta Roux, very ingenious Workmen..

But as his Genius was univer≈øal, and he excelled in all the Parts of De≈øigning; Architecture, which is one of them, took up mo≈øt of his time at Mantua; for be≈øides the Palace of T. which he Built, he made the Church of St. Peter, and ≈øeveral others of a very regular Architecture. It was he al≈øo who found the way of pre≈øerving that Noble City from the Inundations of Water of the Lake, which runs round it; he Built there ≈øeveral Magnificent Palaces, and cau≈øed the great Streets to be enlarged, which are very beautiful.

Julio Romano gained ≈øo much here by the E≈øteem of the Duke, and of the Cardinal his Brother, that he u≈øed to ≈øay, this Painter was
more Ma≈øter of Mantua than he him≈øelf. Thus the E≈øteem and Honour he received of the≈øe two Princes, engaged him to ≈øtay there, and not return to Rome, although the Pope de≈øired it, to make him chief Architect of St. Peter's Church
Julio Romano died at the Age of 45. in 1546. There was made on him this Epitaph,
Romanus Moriens ≈øecum tres Julius Artes
Ab≈øtulit (haud mirum) quatuor unus erat. This great Painter had ≈øeveral Di≈øciples, the be≈øt were Primariccio, a Bolognian, John dal Lione, Raphael dal Colle Borghe≈øe, Benedict Pagni da Pe≈øcia, Figurino da Faen≈øa, Rinaldo and John Bapti≈øta Mantuano, and Fermo Gui≈øoni.
At Cremona, near Mantua, Painting began to flouri≈øh ever ≈øince Pordenone made there ≈øome Pieces in Fre≈øco, and in Oyl, which ≈øhew'd the true Gu≈øto of Painting to Camillo, Son of Boccacino, to Bernard da Gatti, called Soardo, who work'd at Panna, and to Galeazzo Campo, who had three Sons Painters, Julius, Anthony, and Vincent. Julius became famous; his Di≈øciples were his two Brothers, and Lactantius Gambaro of Bre≈øcia: But tho≈øe who did him the mo≈øt Honour, were Four Si≈øters of a Noble Family, who learnt Painting of Julius Campo. They were named Sophonisba, Lucia, and Europa, and Anna Ango≈øciola; Sophonisba was carried by the Duke d'Atra into Spain, and enter'd into the Service of the Queen; the Beauty of her Works being made known to Pope Pius the IVth, he de≈øired to have by her Hand, the Picture of that Queen, which was admired by all Rome; the Pope returned his Thanks to this Illu≈øtrious Paintre≈øs by a Letter; her Two Si≈øters were al≈øo very famous for Painting. Va≈øari, Vita di B. Garo≈øalo, p. 561.
In Sculpture, as well as Painting, there have been Women very famous, particularly Porperzia de' Ro≈ø≈øi of Bologna, who was very much admired in that City for her Painting, and by the Works ≈øhe made in Marble; ≈øhe died in the time that Clement the VIIth came to Bologna to Crown Charles the Vth. This Pope had a great de≈øire to ≈øee this Illu≈øtrious Lady, but ≈øhe died ≈øome days before that Ceremony.
At Bre≈øte there were al≈øo Jerom Mutiano, Jerom Romanino, and Alexander Moretti, who gained con≈øiderable Reputation.
Milan al≈øo brought up ≈øome very good Painters, one of the mo≈øt Ancient of whom, is Bramantine, who work'd for Pope Nicholas the Vth. in the Vatican; but his Painting was taken down, and Raphael has ≈øince painted the ≈øame place. He was al≈øo an Architect, and made ≈øeveral De≈øigns and Buildings at Milan, which were of u≈øe to Bramante, when he fir≈øt ≈øtudied Architecture in that City. At the ≈øame time Bu≈øto, Surnamed Bambaia, di≈øtingui≈øhed him≈øelf among the Sculptors of his time, by ≈øeveral Pieces he made at Milan, and particularly by the Sepulchre of the Count of Foix, which is in the Church of St. Mark, which was made with extraordinary Care and Patience. The Adam and Eve which are on the Front of the Dome at Milan, is of Chri≈øtopher Gobbo, who was Contemporary with Bambaia; there were al≈øo other Sculptors and Architects, who Embelli≈øh'd that City and Dome with their Works, as did Angelo, Il Ceciliano, Tofanon Lombardino, Silvio da Fie≈øole, and Francis Brambilati; but Painting was perfected at Milan, after the Works of Leonardo da Vinci appeared there. One of the mo≈øt Excellent Milane≈øe Painters, was Gaudence: His Works are to be ≈øeen in that City, at Ver≈øailles, and at Veralla. There were ≈øome who imitated Leonardo, as Marco Uggioni; but he to whom, among the Milane≈øe Painting is mo≈øt obliged to, is Paul Lomazzo, who has writ very learnedly on all Parts of the Arts, which Works of his are very u≈øeful for all De≈øigners. His Books were printed at Milan in 1584, and 1590. .

This ≈øhews us, that not only Painting flouri≈øh'd in ≈øeveral Cities of Italy, and at Mantua; but al≈øo that Architecture has always been in≈øeparable from De≈øigning; and more particularly to ≈øhew the Progre≈øs of Architecture after it's arrival. I will begin with it from the time of Brunele≈øchi, 100 Years before Julio Romano.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: Architecture arrived to a very great Excellency at Rome.

div.p: THE famous Ser-Brunele≈øchi began to bring Architecture out of the rude Gothick Manner, which had been practi≈øed at Florence, and other places, down to 1400. For he e≈øtabli≈øhed in that City the u≈øe of the Dorick, Ionick, and Corinthian Orders, in all their Purity, and according to tho≈øe ju≈øt Rules he had ≈øtudied at Rome in the Ancient Buildings.

Leon Bapti≈øta Alberti followed the Foot≈øteps of this Illu≈øtrious Architect and Sculptor, and in Imitation of him continued at Florence the true Gu≈øto of Architecture, by rea≈øon that he was an excellent Geometrician and good De≈øigner. His Treati≈øe of the Orders, and his Works of Architecture, are a proof of it.

The famous Bramante, by his Excellent Architecture, continued to improve the latter part of this Age, as Brunele≈øchi and Leon Bapti≈øta had done; and al≈øo the beginning of the Age, 1500. wherin he lived. Bramante learnt Painting from his Youth, and gained his Livelihood thereby for a long time, in the State of Urbin, (where he was Born) and in ≈øeveral Cities of Lombardy, where he made ≈øeveral Pictures. But as he had al≈øo a Genius for very great things, he went to Milan to con≈øider the Building of the great Church there, then under the Conduct and Management of Cae≈øarianus, a very Ingenious Architect; and Bernardino da Trevio, a Milane≈øe,
al≈øo a good Painter, and Architect, and Engineer, who was very much e≈øteem'd by Leonardo Vinci, though his way of Painting was ≈øomewhat dry.

The Reflections which Bramante made on this famous Church, together with the knowledge he gained by tho≈øe two Architects, who were the Managers and De≈øigners of it, made him have a mind to apply him≈øelf wholly to the Study of Architecture; whereupon he went to Rome, where having kept together what he had gotten by Painting, he ≈øurvey'd with a particular Care and Curio≈øity the magnificent Ancient Buildings of that City, tho≈øe of Tivoli and of La Villa Adriana; his Affection to Architecture led him al≈øo to Naples, to ob≈øerve all the fine Remainders of Antiquity which are there and thereabouts. He there met with the Protection of the Cardinal Archbi≈øhop, who had ≈øuch an E≈øteem for him, that a little after he Engaged him to make at Rome the Cloy≈øter of the Church of Peace. Afterwards he was employed by Pope Alexander VIth. and he ≈øhew'd his Skill in the Architecture of the Palace of the Chancery, and of the Church of St. Laurence in Dama≈øo. He embelli≈øh'd, moreover, ≈øeveral Churches in Rome, by Fronti≈øpieces of his own De≈øigning; that of St. James of the Spaniards, of St. Mary del l'Anima, and of St. Mary del Popolo, are convincing proofs of it; as al≈øo the little Temple of the Dorick Order, which is con≈øecrated to St. Peter in Mont-Orio: The≈øe Works and ≈øeveral others gain'd him ≈øo much reputation, that he was ackowledged the be≈øt Architect of his time; in≈øomuch, that in 1503. Julius the Second being Pope took him into his Service, where he continued
to gain Admiration by his Buildings in the Lodgings of the Vatican, and by tho≈øe of the Palace of Belvidere. But that whereby this famous Architect got the greate≈øt Credit, was his De≈øign of the The De≈øign of St. Peter's Church by Bramante, is to be ≈øeen on the Rever≈øe of the Medals of Julius the Second, and of Leo the Tenth, excellently well Engraven by Carrado≈ø≈øo, who made al≈øo a Medal of Bramante. great Church of St. Peter at Rome, and the Foundation he laid of that incomparable Building
Bramante died in 1514. Aged 70. He was buried in St. Peter's Church, and very much regretted by all the Ingenious in the Arts of De≈øigning; it was he who brought Raphael to Rome, and in≈øtructed him in Architecture.
This Architect, be≈øides the Beauty of the Orders which he brought into u≈øe again, found out ≈øeveral fine things in Architecture, as the way of making Vaults in Plai≈øter, which was al≈øo u≈øed by the Ancients. Va≈øari. Vit. del Bramante.
. Raphael Urbin, after the Death of Bramante, took care of the Architecture of that Church; and there is al≈øo to be ≈øeen of his, the Chappel of Chigi in St. Mary del Popolo; but Death, which at 37 Years of Age put a period to his Life, has deprived us of tho≈øe excellent Works which otherwi≈øe he would have left to Po≈øterity.

Architecture continued at Rome in its Excellence by Balda≈ø≈øare
Balda≈ø≈øare Peruzzi of Siena, from his Youth learned De≈øigning and Painting at Siena; afterwards he went to Rome, and painted in Fre≈øco the great Altar of St. Humphry, and two Chappels at St. Roch; afterwards Augu≈øtine Chigi contracted
a Friend≈øhip with him, which fir≈øt induc'd him to ≈øtudy Architecture, and make him the Model of his Palace de Chigi, in the Street of Longare, where he painted ≈øeveral Figures, and fine Pieces of Per≈øpective, wherein he was Excellent. Julius the Second employ'd him to Paint in the Vatican; and he painted ≈øeveral Fronts of Palaces at Rome, after which he was ≈øent for to Bologna to De≈øign the Portico of St. Petronio, and to ≈øeveral other Parts in Italy; as to Carpi, where the great Church is of his doing, as al≈øo that of St. Nicholas; afterwards he returned to Rome, where he built the Palaces, which are next that of the Farne≈øe's: and Pope Leo the Tenth employ'd him al≈øo in ≈øeveral things, and among the re≈øt, to Paint ≈øome Scenes for Comedies, which were ≈øo much the more ≈øurprizing, becau≈øe it was Balda≈ø≈øare who fir≈øt brought them into u≈øe; for he was very Excellent in placing Lights true in Per≈øpective. It was he who continued on the great Chappel of St. Peter, which Bramante had begun. But in 1527. when Rome was ≈øacked by the Spaniards, Balda≈ø≈øare was ≈øo unfortunate as to be taken Pri≈øoner, and not only lo≈øt all he had, but was very ill treated: Becau≈øe he had a good Pre≈øence, the Spaniards took him for a Prie≈øt in di≈øgui≈øe; and having afterwards under≈øtood that he was a Painter, and one of tho≈øe who were e≈øteemed by Charles de Bourbon, they made him draw the Portrait of that Prince after his Death, by which means Balda≈ø≈øare obtain'd his Liberty, and went to Siena ≈øtrip'd of all he had. After the Wars were ended he return'd to Rome, where he continued to Work, and Comment on Vitruvius, which he did not fini≈øh by rea≈øon Death prevented him: He was buried in the Rotunda near Raphael, with this Epitaph, Baltha≈øari Perutio Senen≈øi, Viro & Pictura, & Architectura, alii≈øque ingeniorum artibus adeo excellenti, ut ≈øi Pri≈øcorum occubui≈ø≈øet temporibus, no≈øtra illum felicius legerent. Vix. Ann. LV. Men≈øes XI. Dies XX.
Lucretia, & Jo. Salu≈øtius optimo Conjugi, & Parenti, non ≈øine lacrymis Simonis, Honorii, Claudii, Aemilioe, ac Sulpitiae minorum filiorum, dolentes po≈øuerunt. Die 4 Januarii, M. D. XXXVI.
Peruzzi, where are to be ≈øeen of his de≈øigning ≈øome Palaces of a fine and elegant Proportion, which command the Attention and Admiration of the Spectators, filling them with an agreeable plea≈øure in con≈øidering their Beauty, the effect of a rare De≈øignment; for Balthazar excelled in Painting and Per≈øpective,
before he practi≈øed Architecture, and had in that Art ≈øeveral Di≈øciples; Serlio was one of the fir≈øt, who made any Proficiency by the De≈øigns of Balthazzar, for he compo≈øed tho≈øe Books we have under the Name of Seba≈øtiano Serlio Bologne≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.

argument.p: Architecture began to revive in the State of Venice.

div.p: GOOD Architecture began to revive in the Provinces of the Republick of Venice, according to the true Gu≈øto of the Ancients, for there were ≈øeveral Illu≈øtrious Architects who came from Verona, who were happy in being Born in a City where there were ≈øo many Relicks of fine Architecture: For it is mo≈øt certain that the be≈øt Precepts which can be given in the Arts of De≈øigning, are fine Examples, whereon Youth Ca≈øting their Eyes and Thoughts with a particular Inclination for De≈øigning, cannot but ≈øucceed: And this is an Advantage which the Italians have had above other Nations, who have render'd them≈øelves famous in Architecture, Sculpture, and Painting; in≈øomuch, that it is not a wonder that in the la≈øt Age they have ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed others.

Tho≈øe Ingenious Verone≈øe Architects, were Joconde, Michael San Michael, and John Maria Falconetti. Joconde was called Fryer John Joconde, ever ≈øince he wore the Habit of the Dominicans;
and though his fir≈øt Talents were Learning and Theology, he was notwith≈øtanding an excellent Architect, and learned in Per≈øpective; for from his Youth he exerci≈øed him≈øelf in the true ancient way of Architecture, by his Studies after the Theaters, Amphitheaters, Triumphal-Arches, and other Relicks of Ancient Buildings, which make Verona famous.

When Joconde ≈øet him≈øelf to practi≈øe this Art, he was immediately very much favoured by Maximilian, who gave him Orders to rebuild at Verona the Bridge, which is called the Stone-Bridge, and which is very con≈øiderable, by rea≈øon of the Rapidity of the River, and its moving Bottom. Joconde from his Youth had ≈øtudied the Antiquities at Rome, and even the very In≈øcriptions, whereof he compo≈øed a very fine Book, which was pre≈øented to the old Duke Laurence de Medicis. He al≈øo made Notes on Cae≈øar's Commentaries, and de≈øign'd the De≈øcription of the Bridge, which that Emperor made over the Rhine. After this Joconde was ≈øent for from Rome by Lewis the Twelfth, for whom he rai≈øed ≈øeveral Buildings; the mo≈øt famous were the Bridges of Notre Dame at Paris, which this Prince order'd him to make, on the Building whereof Sannazar, his Friend, made this Epigram,

q.l: Jocundus geminum impo≈øuit tibi Sequana Pontem.
Hunc tu jure potes dicere Pontificem.

div.p:
But Joconde at his return to Rome, by the Death of Bramante, was made one of the Surveyors of the Fabrick of St. Peter, with Raphael d'Urbin, and Anthony Sangallo. Joconde al≈øo made at Venice ≈øome ≈øurprizing Works, for he found out the
Invention of turning away part of the Waters of the Brinte, that they ≈øhould not fill the Common Shores of that City with Sand and Earth, which that River brought down along with it, and by the≈øe means he pre≈øerv'd Venice from the Accidents which threatned it. Budaeus ≈øays in Honour of this Great Man, that he return'd Thanks to God that he had ≈øo good a Ma≈øter in Architecture, as Joconde, who exceeded Vitruvius.

Michael San Michel, ≈øtudied the Principles of Architecture at Verona, under his Father and Uncle, who were very good Architects; but at Sixteen Years of Age he went to Rome, and there mea≈øured the fine Ancient Buildings round about it, and thereby became skilled in every part of Architecture, in≈øomuch that Pope Clement VIIth. gave him a Pen≈øion to go with Sangallo, and Fortify the Frontiers of the Eccle≈øia≈øtick State, particularly Parma and Placentia. Afterwards he returned to Verona, who≈øe fine Gates he made, and the Republick employ'd him in the Principal Buildings of the State, in the Levant, and on the Terra Firma, among which may be reckoned the Fortre≈øs of Lido.

Moreover, John Maria Falconetti, who was al≈øo of Verona, was a very famous Architect: He learnt Painting of his Father; but becau≈øe he did not get much by it, he ≈øet him≈øelf to Study the Antiquities of the City; after which he went to Rome and Naples, to Survey the Buildings of the Ancients, where he employ'd him≈øelf for the ≈øpace of twelve Years, and omitted nothing in his De≈øigns, neither there, nor in the Parts round about. But as he had not ≈øufficient Means to continue his Studies long, he employ'd
him≈øelf ≈øome Days in the Week in Painting, thereby to ≈øupply his Nece≈ø≈øities.

Afterwards returning to Verona, and finding there no opportunity of employing him≈øelf in Architecture, he found him≈øelf obliged to take up Painting again; but through good luck he found in that City Signior Cornaro, who was a great lover of Architecture, who cau≈øed him to come to his Hou≈øe, where he dwelt twenty one Years; he employ'd him≈øelf all this while in Working, and exerci≈øing that Art, which Falconetti had ≈øo much ≈øtudied. Thus the≈øe three Illu≈øtrious Architects of Verona introduced the true Gu≈øto and Way of Building into the Venetian State.

This true and regular Way of Building was continued there, and even augmented by James San≈øovino, a Florentine, who embelli≈øh'd Venice with the greate≈øt and mo≈øt regular Buildings that are there to be ≈øeen.

The famous San≈øovino began from his Youth to ≈øtudy De≈øigning and Sculpture at Florence, which he very ≈øucce≈øsfully practi≈øed; he entertain'd a great Re≈øpect for Andrew del Sarto, an Excellent Painter. After this he went to Rome, where he got acquainted with Raphael and Bramante, who did him Ju≈øtice in their Recommendations of his Skill to Leo the Tenth.
The French, and the Spaniards, and the Germans, had at that time great Inclinations to build them≈øelves National Churches at Rome. The Florentines al≈øo obtain'd the ≈øame favour from the Pope.

The Florentines cau≈øed ≈øeveral Models to be made by Raphael, Balda≈ø≈øare, Anthony Sangallo, and San≈øovino. It was the De≈øign of this la≈øt
that they cho≈øe: And San≈øovino began to build the Church of St. John for the Florentines according to the Model he had made of it. But this building was di≈øcontiuned during the Popedom of Adrian the VIth, a Fleming by his Countrey, who had no affection nor gu≈øt for the Arts of De≈øigning: In≈øomuch, that if he had reigned long the≈øe Arts would have infallibly ≈øunk into their old ob≈øcurity, at lea≈øt at Rome.

Clement the VIIth ≈øucceeded him, and prevented this misfortune; for he ≈øet to Work all the Ingenious in the≈øe Arts: And James San≈øovino continued by the≈øe means the Fabrick of the Church of the Florentines till the Year 1527, wherein the Army of Charles the Vth be≈øieged Rome, which cha≈øed away from that City a great Number of excellent Men. San≈øovino
James San≈øovino died at Venice at the Age of 78 Years; he brought up ≈øeveral Di≈øciples at Florence and at Venice, who were Nicholas, called il Tribolo, who wrought in the Abby of Mount Ca≈ø≈øin, Jerom de Ferrara, who wrought much at Loretta and Venice. James Colonna learn'd al≈øo Sculpture of San≈øovino, and died at Bologna, Titian da Padua, Peter de Salo, James Alexander Vittoria of Trente, Thomas de Lugan, James Bre≈ø≈øan, Bartholomew Amannatti and Dane≈øe Catanee who were all good Sculptors and Architects. retired to Venice to go thence to France into the Service of Francis the I≈øt who very much de≈øired him.

But being arrived at Venice with a de≈øign to get ≈øomething there, becau≈øe he had lo≈øt all his Goods at the pillaging of Rome; his Merit was repre≈øented to the Doge Gritti, and that he could prevent the Ruine which threatned the Dome of St. Mark. Immediately by the Order of the Doge San≈øovino undertook it, and by the help of ≈øome pieces of Timber and Iron-bands which he
invented, he ≈øet this great Work out of danger. This gain'd him ≈øo much Reputation that the Super-intendency of the Works of the Dukedom, which became vacant, was given him.

The fir≈øt Work which he made for the Republick was Zecca, which is the Chamber for the Money, or Trea≈øury, with a great deal of beauty and advantage: Afterwards he was employ'd about the Fortifications of the Venetian State. Afterwards he built the new Architecture that embelli≈øhes the Palace of St. Mark. He made al≈øo ≈øeveral Works of Bra≈øs and Marble in the Church; and con≈øidering all the fine Structures wherewith he enrich'd Venice, we may ≈øay of him that he advanced Architecture in that City to its highe≈øt Perfection.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: Michael Angelo made Architecture, Sculpture, and the true Way of De≈øigning flouri≈øh at Rome.

div.p: THE great Michael Angelo Buonaruoti, had the ≈øame Honour at Florence and Rome as San≈øovino at Venice: For he ≈øhewed his Capacity in Architecture in tho≈øe two Cities, and in the la≈øt Age advanced that Art to its highe≈øt Perfection. The rea≈øon of this is very evident and no ways ≈øurprizing, for being the greate≈øt De≈øigner of his Time he became al≈øo the greate≈øt Architect, when he apply'd his Time wholly to it as he did during his la≈øt Years.

Michael Angelo was born at Florence in 1474, with a natural Inclination for De≈øigning; for although in his Youth he was brought up to Learning, notwith≈øtanding he bu≈øied him≈øelf always in private about De≈øigning: And as his Father ≈øaw that he had a very great Inclination for Painting, he put him to Dominick Ghirlandaio, for him to in≈øtruct him therein; and in a little time Michael Angelo di≈øtingui≈øh'd him≈øelf from other Di≈øciples, by the ≈øurprizing Facility wherewith he de≈øigned: This great Genius was very fortunately favoured by Prince Laurence de Medicis, by rea≈øon of the great Pa≈ø≈øion this Prince had to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Revival of the Arts, by a≈ø≈øi≈øting Men skilled and learned therein. This generous Temper made him e≈øtabli≈øh in the Gallery of his Gardens an Academy which he fill'd with fine Pictures and Pieces of Sculpture both Ancient and Modern. Afterwards he cau≈øed to be ≈øought out at Florence tho≈øe Young De≈øigners who promi≈øed mo≈øt, to whom he allow'd Pen≈øions to promote the conveniency of their Studies. Tho≈øe of the School of Ghirlandaio were cho≈øen the fir≈øt, and particularly Michael Angelo, who had ≈øo lively a Genius for all the Parts of De≈øigning, that one day having taken up a piece of Marble, he ≈øet about making a Head, tho' as yet he had never handled a Chi≈øel; which ≈øo much ≈øurprized Prince Laurence, that he conceived ≈øo great an Affection for Michael Angelo, that be≈øides the Pen≈øion he allow'd him, he did him the Honour to admit him to his own Table, and gave him a Lodging in his Palace. After the Death of this Prince, his Succe≈ø≈øor Peter de Medicis, continued to Michael Angelo the ≈øame Affection he had been favoured with by the Great Duke his Father.

Signor Soderini Gonfaloniere of the ≈øame Republick, had no le≈øs e≈øteem for this ingenious Man than the≈øe two Princes; and about the ≈øame time Michael Angelo made a Cupid of Marble which was ≈øent to Rome, and hidden under Ground, to pretend that it was an Ancient one: It was afterwards dug up and ≈øold for ≈øuch to Cardinal St. George, and this Cupid pa≈ø≈øed for one of the mo≈øt rare and fine Pieces of Antiquity. Hereby this famous Sculptor acquired a great Reputation at Rome; whither he went for the fir≈øt time: He continued Sculpture there with a great Application, and made a Bacchus of Marble with ≈øeveral other admirable Statues. At his return to Florence he apply'd him≈øelf with the ≈øame diligence to that fine Art, and made a Marble David, which was ≈øet up before the Palace. Peter Soderini, and all the Citizens were ≈øo charmed with this Piece, that they obliged this famous De≈øigner to make ≈øome more of them, ≈øome in Bra≈øs and others in Painting. Then Gonfaloniere ordered him to Paint one half of the Council Hall, and Leonardo da Vinci the other.

It was here that Michael Angelo made a Piece to Parallel that of Leonardo da Vinci which was ≈øo famous. Michael Angelo in this Work gave proofs of the Excellence of his De≈øigning, both in re≈øpect of the compo≈øition of the Subject, which was the War of Pi≈øa, and in his correctne≈øs in naked Figures: And to have an opportunity of ≈øhewing it the better, he cho≈øe the time when ≈øeveral of the Soldiers u≈øed to bath them≈øelves in the River Arno, to introduce into his De≈øigning naked Figures, in which he was Excellent; it was this famous Piece that gave Raphael and ≈øeveral others an in≈øight to the Perfection of De≈øigning.

Julius the IId being rai≈øed to the Papal Chair ≈øent for Michal Angelo to Rome, re≈øolving to engage him to make him a Mau≈øoleum in St. Peter's ad vincula. Here is to be ≈øeen that fine Figure of Mo≈øes and ≈øeveral others, and the excellent Architecture, which joined together make this fine Sepulcher. This great De≈øign was not executed according to the largene≈øs of its fir≈øt Model, but was reduced to what it is, whence France has the Honour of two Statues of Marble which were to be placed on each ≈øide of the Sepulcher, and which are at pre≈øent in the Ca≈øtle of Richelieu.

The working of this Mau≈øoleum was for a long time interrupted, becau≈øe the Pope ≈øet Michael Angelo to Paint in Fre≈øco the arched Ceiling of the Chappel of Sixtus the IVth, which ≈øo much rai≈øed his Reputation, that be≈øides the general Applau≈øe he received at Rome, he received con≈øiderable Pre≈øents from Pope Julius: He de≈øerved both the one and the other; for he alone painted that Vault after ≈øo admirable a way, that the famous Caraches, who came after him, took thence their magnificent Ideas in the Painting of the Palace of Farne≈øe at Rome. Julius the IId being dead, Leo the Xth his Succe≈ø≈øor honoured Michael Angelo no le≈øs than he had done, for he employ'd him in the Architecture of the Front of St. Laurence at Florence, and his Model gained more E≈øteem than any other.

After this in the Popedom of Clement the VIIth, he made in the Ve≈øtry of the ≈øame Church, the Sepulcher of the Hou≈øe of Medicis, and that Sepulcher even till this time has pa≈ø≈øed for a wonder both of Architecture and Sculpture.

This excellent Per≈øon moreover ≈øhewed that he was Ignorant in nothing in all the Arts of De≈øigning; for he al≈øo fortified the Mount St. Miniate at Florence, and thereby hindered their Enemies from becoming Ma≈øters of it.

But when the Wars of Italy in 1525 obliged ≈øeveral ingenious Arti≈øts to leave Rome and Florence, Michael Angelo was one of that Number, and went to Venice, where the Doge Gritti, to whom he had the honour to be known, cau≈øed him to make the De≈øign of the Bridge of Realto, which is one of the Ma≈øterpieces of Architecture. He painted in that City ≈øome Pictures, and among others that of Leda, which he gave to the Duke of Ferrara, who ≈øent it to Francis the I≈øt.

The Wars of Italy being ended, Michael Angelo returned to Rome, and there fini≈øhed the Sepulcher of Julius the IId, after which he painted by order of Pope Paul the IIId the great Front of the Altar, whereon he repre≈øented the la≈øt Judgment, and it was this only which was not fini≈øhed of all the Paintings of this Chappel. The Fame of this great Work in Fre≈øco, which is all over the World, ≈øufficiently denotes its Excellence.

Michael Angelo in his old Age apply'd him≈øelf more to Architecture than Painting and Sculpture, becau≈øe after the death of Antony Sangallo Architect, the Pope preferr'd Michael Angelo to any other, and made him chief Architect of the Fabrick of St. Peter, and of the Apo≈øtolick Chamber, although he would have excu≈øed him≈øelf from it.

Having accepted this Charge he went to St. Peter's, to ≈øee the Model of Sangallo, to fini≈øh what remain'd to be built of that great Church, and after having examined it, he publickly declared
that that Architect had made the Model of it without any Art, becau≈øe without ≈øide he had made too many Pillars, one upon another, and unnce≈ø≈øary Spires, and too many ≈ømall Branchings and little Members, which are quite contrary to good Architecture; la≈øtly, that this Model was of a Gu≈øto rather Barbarous than Ancient: Be≈øides this he ≈øhew'd that the execution or performance of it would co≈øt a Million more than one that he would make.

Michael Angelo cau≈øed another Model to be made in fifteen days time which co≈øt only five hundred Crowns, whereas that of Sangallo co≈øt four thou≈øand, and ≈øeveral Years work; ≈øo that at la≈øt this great Church was fini≈øhed according to the De≈øign of Michael Angelo in the beauty we ≈øee it now, excepting the Front, which is not his, nor ≈øo well done as the Architecture of the outermo≈øt Tower and the back Part of that Church. While Michael Angelo carried on this Building, he al≈øo made ≈øeveral others which make part of the beauty of Rome: Such as the Palace of Farne≈øe, and the Capitol, which excite the Admiration both of Architects and other Ingenious Men.

The fine Pieces of
Michael Angelo died at Rome the 17th February 1564: He was almo≈øt ninety Years of Age. This great Man, be≈øides the Affection of ≈øeven Popes whom he ≈øerved, gained a very great Reputation with Solyman, Emperor of the Turks, with Francis the 1≈øt, Charles the Vth, the Republick of Venice, and all the Princes of Italy, particularly with the great Duke of Tu≈øcany, who reigned at the ≈øame time this illu≈øtrious De≈øigner died: For when his Body was in the Church of Sancto Apo≈øtolo, and the Pope was about to ≈øet up a fine Sepulcher for him: This great Duke cau≈øed his Body to be privately fetch'd away to bury it in his Capital City; and ≈øince he was not ≈øo happy as to have him alive, he was re≈øolved to have him dead; And performed his Funeral ob≈øequies with all imaginable Pomp and Splendor. This Pomp was celebrated in the Church of St. Cro≈øs at Florence, attended by all the Gentlemen of the Academy of De≈øign; who, on that occa≈øion gave ≈øufficient Te≈øtimony of the E≈øteem they had for this their Ma≈øter, by the magnificent Repre≈øentation, which the Italians call Catafalco, and adorning the whole Church with Painting and Sculpture and Lights. A Panegyrick was there pronounced over him by Me≈ø≈ør. Benedetto Varchi, and on the Repre≈øentation was to be read this EPITAPH;
Collegium Pictorum, Statuariorum, Architectorum, au≈øpicio ope
que ≈øibi prompta Co≈ømi Ducis, auctoris ≈øuorum commodorum, ≈øu≈øpiciens ≈øingularem virtutem Micha√´lis Angeli Bonarotae; intelligen≈ø
que quanto ≈øibi auxilio ≈øemper fuerint praeclara ip≈øius opera, ≈øtuduit ≈øe gratum erga illum o≈øtendere, ≈øummum omnium qui unquam fuerint, P. S. A. ide√≥que monumentum hoc ≈øuis manibus extructum, magno animi ardore, ip≈øius memoriae dedicavit.
After the≈øe ≈øumptuous Ob≈øequies, the Great Duke order'd an honourable Place in this Church to build the Tomb of Michael Angelo according to the De≈øign of George Va≈øari: It is inrich'd with three great Marble Figures, repre≈øenting Painting, Sculpture and Architecture, which were made by Bapti≈øta Lorenzi, and Giovanni dell'opera, and Valerio Cioli, all three ingenious Florentine Sculptors.
Michael Angelo in Painting and Sculpture and Architecture, and his other good Qualities had gain'd him ≈øuch an E≈øteem
with the Popes whom he had the Honour to ≈øerve; that Julius the IIId u≈øed to make him ≈øit by him and talk with him concerning the Arts of De≈øigning: And oftentimes this Pope would take his Part again≈øt tho≈øe who criticiz'd upon him. By all the≈øe Honours which Michael Angelo received, and the univer≈øal Applau≈øe that was given to all his Works; we may conclude that it was this famous De≈øigner, who, in that Age advanced Sculpture and Architecture with the true Way of De≈øigning to the highe≈øt degree of Perfection that ever they arrived to, at Rome and Florence.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

argument.p: Several Di≈øciples of Michael Angelo, and Raphael, continued the Excellency of Painting and Architecture at Rome.

div.p:
IN the time of Michael Angelo there was at Rome Seba≈øtian
Seba≈øtian the Venetian was ≈øurnamed Frate del Piombo, which is a Charge of the Apo≈øtolick Chamber, which he obtain'd of the Pope on condition to pay a Pen≈øion to John d'Udine, who had been a≈ø≈øi≈øtant to him in obtaining that Office. This afforded means to Seba≈øtian to live without his Profe≈ø≈øion, and made him almo≈øt leave off Painting. He had a ≈øecret Compo≈øition which he made of Lime mixed with Ma≈øtick and Grecian Pitch melted down together, and laying that mixture on the Walls, mixed with ≈ølack Lime that had been heated red hot in the Fire, prevents Painting in Oyl on the Walls from growing Black, and being ≈øpoiled by the Wet: He died in 1547. Va≈øari V. di Fra. S. Veni. the Venetian, afterwards call'd Frate del Piombo. He had learnt of John Bellin at Venice the Principles of Painting, and of Georgeone his ≈øecond Ma≈øter the true Way of Colouring. This fine Way of Colouring gain'd him the Friend≈øhip of Michael Angelo, when Seba≈øtian came to Rome; Michael Angelo thought that this his grand Manner of De≈øigning join'd with that of Colouring, would excel the Pieces of Raphael d'Urbin, but it did not ≈øucceed.
But the favour and protection which Seba≈øtian received from Michael Angelo made him Prefer him to Bapti≈øta Franco, to Perin del Vago, to Balda≈ø≈øar Perruzzi and other Di≈øciples of Raphael.

But the≈øe ingenious Di≈øciples, tho' they did not equal him, yet they had Qualities which made them always e≈øteemed, and they very much contributed to the perfection of the Arts of De≈øigning, as did al≈øo John d'Udine who had been one of them, who Painted all the Animals, the Flowers and Fruits which are in the Works of Raphael.

This John had al≈øo a great Genius at inventing tho≈øe ≈øorts of Ornaments, which are called Grote≈øque. This is to be ≈øeen by tho≈øe he painted in the Rooms in the Vatican, and by the excellent De≈øigns for Tapi≈øtry, which he made of that ≈øort of Work, although it is agreed that it might have been done after the ancient Pla≈øter, as ≈øome was which was found about that time in the Rooms in the Gardens of Titus, and tho≈øe which were ≈øtill remaining in the Temple of Peace, and in the City Adriana, and other ancient Buildings. Notwith≈øtanding all the De≈øigns which were made by John d'Udine
John d'Udine died at Rome in 1564, and was buried in the round Church near Raphael d'Urbin his Ma≈øter.
To the ≈øame City of Udine, and that of Frioul we are obliged for a great Number of good Painters, as Pellegrino and John Martin d'Udine who were Di≈øciples of John Bellin: Pellegrino was the mo≈øt Ingenious and very much beloved by the Dukes of Ferrara; he brought up ≈øeveral Di≈øciples. But the mo≈øt Famous of the Painters of this Province was John Antony Licinio born at Pordenone, a Village di≈øtant from Udina twenty five Miles; he had no other in≈øtructor than Nature, which he imitated from his Youth; he very much practi≈øed Painting in Fre≈øco in the neighbouring Villages: Afterwards he went to Udina where he painted ≈øeveral Pieces in Oyl and in Fre≈øco, as as al≈øo at Venice and Genoua. He was commonly called Pordenone. The way of Georgeone plea≈øed him better than any other. He died in 1540, aged fifty ≈øix Years. Ridolfi V. de Pitt. Veneti.
are ≈øo
fine that it is que≈øtioned whether tho≈øe of the Ancients were more Excellent; for this John was not only an excellent Painter, but al≈øo a very ingenious Sculptor and worker in Plai≈øter, as is apparent in the ≈ømall Figures of that ≈øort of work which he has mixed among the Ornaments of the Apartments of the Vatican, in≈øomuch that he de≈øerves to be e≈øteemed as the Reviver of Stucco-Work for the perfection to which he carri'd it: For it was he, who by a through examination of the Materials whereof the ancient Pla≈øter was compo≈øed, found that it was made of Lime mixed with Powder of Marble, to give it duration and make it receive a fine Poli≈øh and Shining, as Pla≈øter will have when it is worked with care.

John Francis ≈øurnamed Il Fattore of Florence was a Di≈øciple of Raphael with Julio Romano; and may be ju≈øtly con≈øidered as a Di≈øciple of ≈øo worthy a Ma≈øter, for after the death of that famous Painter, they jointly fini≈øhed, he and Julio, the great Hall of the Vatican, where they painted the Hi≈øtories of Con≈øtantine.

Perrin
Perrin del Vago was al≈øo buried in the round Church in 1547, at the Age of forty ≈øeven; the Principal Di≈øciples of Perrin were Jerom Siciolante de Sermonette and Marcellus Mantuanus. del Vago a Florentine, and his Brother-in-Law, were al≈øo Di≈øciples of Raphael; for Perrin being at Rome where he then ≈øtudied Antiquities, John d'Udine propo≈øed to Raphael to work in Pla≈øter, and on Painting the Rooms of the Vatican which were then doing, and he painted ≈øeveral of them with Hi≈øtories out of the Old Te≈øtament which were very well done. He afterwards made at Rome, after the death of Raphael
≈øome fine Pieces in Fre≈øco, at the Church of the Trinity on the Hill, at St. Marcellus, and ≈øeveral other Churches.

But the mo≈øt con≈øiderable Piece of Perrin del Vago, was the Palace which Prince Doria cau≈øed him to build at Genoua, after a Model of this famous Painter's, wherein he al≈øo did the Painting and the Pla≈øter work, which ≈øtill render that Building the fine≈øt and mo≈øt con≈øiderable in all that City.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.

argument.p: At Florence the true Way of Sculpture and Painting was continued by ≈øome ingenious Men.

div.p:
BACCIO
Baccio was born in 1487; and died at ≈øeventy two Years of Age: He is accu≈øed of having taken to pieces the fine Paintings of Leonardo da Vinci and Michael Angelo, which they had done in the Council Hall, whither all the Di≈øigners of Florence went afterwards to Study, and that out of Envy to Michael Angelo.
Among the re≈øt who ≈øtudied this fine Piece of Michael Angelo, Seba≈øtian called Ari≈øtotle of St. Gal drew it in little, and kept it very carefully, e≈øpecially ≈øince the Original was ruined. Afterwards in 1540 at the per≈øwa≈øion of Va≈øari his Friend, he painted it in Oyl in two Colours only; Giovo ≈øent this Picture into France to King Francis.
Bandinelli although he died before Michael Angelo, may notwith≈øtanding be accounted one who imitated his Manner: For after he had learn'd the Trade of a Gold≈ømith at
Florence, he very eagerly ≈øtudied De≈øigning, and e≈øpecially that famous Piece of Michael Angelo which was in the Council Hall, ≈øo that he had the Advantage of acquiring a correct Way of De≈øigning, to which he joined the Study of Anatomy. Baccio gave proof of his Skill by his Works, and by ≈øome Stamps he cau≈øed to be engraved by Augu≈øtin Venetianus. He al≈øo practi≈øed Sculpture with a great deal of Applau≈øe; for on account of that, and a fine Print of the Martyrdom of St. Laurence, which he procured Mark Antony to Engrave, Pope Clement the VIIth honour'd him with the Order of Knigthood of St. Peter. His chief Works in Marble were, the great Figure of Hercules with Cacus, which is in the Square of the Palace of Florence: He made this Piece to accompany that of Michael Angelo, and that of Benvenuto Cellini which ≈øtood in the ≈øame Square. The Piece of Adam and Eve, which is at the Altar in the Cathedral of Florence, is one of his be≈øt and mo≈øt con≈øiderable Works.

Benvenuto Cellini was a Per≈øon of particular Merit, he was an excellent Gold≈ømith, and compo≈øed a Book which treats of that Art, and the way of ca≈øting Figures in Bra≈øs. He came into France to ≈øerve Francis the I≈øt, for whom he made ≈øeveral Pieces in that Metal: And he had a peculiar Excellence in engraving Coins for Medals and Money.

We ought to place among the Illu≈øtrious Tu≈øcans of that time Daniel da
Daniel da Volterra died at fifty ≈øeven Years of Age. Volterra, equally Excellent in Painting, Sculpture and Architecture; he learnt of Balda≈ø≈øare Perruzzi, afterwards he
was employ'd under Perin del Vaga in the Church of Trinity del Monte: And there built the fine Chappel of St. Helen in that Church, and painted over again≈øt it another ju≈øt like it.

The Pictures in Fre≈øco which he there made cannot be enough admired, chiefly that of the De≈øcent from the Cro≈øs of our Saviour, the Beauty whereof is ≈øufficiently known throughout the World, by rea≈øon of the great Number of Copies of it which are to be ≈øeen throughout all Europe. The Excellence of this Picture appears in the Compo≈øition, lively Expre≈ø≈øion and correctne≈øs of De≈øign, and the excellency of the Painting. One of his be≈øt Pieces of Sculpture is the Brazen Hor≈øe in the Royal Square at Paris.

Robert Strozzi had Commi≈ø≈øion from Queen Katharine de Medicis to procure Michael Angelo to make it, but he excu≈øed him≈øelf by rea≈øon of his great Age, and advi≈øed this Lord to get Daniel da Volterra to do it, who accordingly undertook it; but he was ≈øo unfortunate as to mi≈øs the fir≈øt Ca≈øt, but the ≈øecond time he ≈øucceeded. But Death prevented him before he had fini≈øhed the Statue of Henry the IId, who was to be ≈øet on the Hor≈øe. Thus this Work remain'd imperfect by the Death of Daniel da Volterra, and a long time after under Lewis the XIIIth it was carried away from Rome, and the Figure of that King ≈øet up in its room, as we ≈øee it at this day in the Royal Square.

There were other famous Tu≈øcan Painters
Dominick Beccafumi of Siena was al≈øo one of the be≈øt Painters of Tu≈øcany. He had a natural Inclination for De≈øigning, which made him often of his own acccord De≈øign on the Sand as he kept his Flocks. Afterwards he ≈øtudied at Siena the Works of Peter Perugin, and after that at Rome he ≈øtudied tho≈øe of Michael Angelo and Raphael; then he went to dwell at Siena, where he did ≈øeveral Pieces of Painting in the Church of the Dome and in other Places which were very much e≈øteemed. His A≈ø≈øi≈øtant at Siena was Sodoma, who gain'd a very good Reputation. Beccafumi died in 1549, at ≈øixty five Years of Age. appear'd at Florence, at the ≈øame time as niel da Volterra at Rome, among whom were Jacob
James da Puntormo was born in 1493, and lived 65 Years; Bronzin learnt of him, and may pa≈øs for his Di≈øciple. da Puntormo, Francis Bronzin his Di≈øciple, and Salviati. Puntormo began under Leonardo da Vinci, and in 1512 he continued to perfect him≈øelf with Andrew del Sarto.
Bronzin was in nothing Inferiour to him, and there are to be ≈øeen of his Hand ≈øome Pictures excellently well done.

Salviati
Francis Salviati was born in 1510, and died at Rome in 1563. learnt De≈øigning in the School of Baccio Bandinelli, and Painting of Andrew del Sarto. After having work'd for ≈øome time at Florence and at Rome, he came in the Year 1554 into France, where he was very well received by Primaticcio then chief Painter and Architect to the King; but as ≈øoon as Salviati ≈øaw the Works of Ro≈ø≈øo, who had been chief Painter to the King, and tho≈øe of other Painters, he affected to find Faults in them, which rai≈øed great Expectations of what he would do: He was emploied by the Cardinal de Lorrain to Paint in his Ca≈øtle of Dampierre, but not being plea≈øed in France he returned to his own Country.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.

argument.p: The Cities of Ferrara, and others of Lombardy and Urbin, furni≈øh'd the World with ≈øeveral good Painters.

div.p: FLORENCE was not the only City of Italy, which bred Excellent Painters: for Ferrara had ≈øeveral, Do≈ø≈øo and Bapti≈øta his Brother were very ingenious. Do≈ø≈øo was very much extolled by the famous Ario≈øto, and cheri≈øhed till his Death by the Generous Prince Alphon≈øus of Ferrara.

Alphon≈øus Lombardi, an Excellent Sculptor, was al≈øo Born in the ≈øame City; he made ≈øeveral Portraits, witne≈øs that which he made at Bologna, of the Emperor Charles the V. whereby he gain'd very great Applau≈øe, with an honourable Recompence from that Prince.

But one of the be≈øt Painters of Ferrara, was Benvenuto Garofalo
Benvenuto Garofalo was Born at Ferrara, in 1481. Be≈øides Raphael, who was his Friend, he al≈øo contracted Friend≈øhip with Georgeone, Titian, and Julio Romano; he grew Blind towards the latter end of his Life, and continued ≈øo for nine Years; he died in 1550. at Seventy eight Years of Age; one of his be≈øt Pupils was Jerom de Carpi, who went to Copy the fine Pieces of Correggio at Modena, and at Parma; afterwards he work'd at Bologna and Ferrara, where he made a large Venus with Cupids, which the Duke ≈øent to King Francis; this Picture is very much prai≈øed by Va≈øari; he dy'd in the Year 1556. 55 Years of Age.
There was al≈øo of Ferrara, Jerom a Sculptor; he work'd ≈øince Andrew Contucci, his Ma≈øter, ≈øeveral Pieces in Marble in the Church of Loretta, where he was employed twenty ≈øix Years without any Interruption. ; he began to learn Painting
Ferrara, and Cremona, and at Mantua under Corta Ferrara. At nineteen Years of Age he went to Rome for fifteen Months, then he return'd to Mantua, and thence to Rome again, where the Works of Raphael, and Michael Angelo's grand Gu≈øto of De≈øigning charmed him ≈øo much, that he repented he had ≈øpent his Youth in ≈øtudying the Lombard Manner.

This made him re≈øolve to leave them, and become a Di≈øciple and Imitator of Raphael, during the ≈øpace of two Years, becau≈øe he found him≈øelf very much in favour with that great Man, whom he very unwillingly left for ≈øome Affairs of his Family, which obliged him to dwell at Ferrara.

Benvenuto Garofalo was there very much e≈øteemed by the Duke, and the principal Per≈øonages of that City, for whom he painted ≈øeveral Pieces, in the Churches, and in particular Hou≈øes; his Works were very beautiful, by rea≈øon he followed very good and ju≈øt Principles, which he received from Raphael, and took particular care to joyn thereunto the Imitation of the be≈øt Nature.

The State of Urbin continued to yield ingenious Men; and the Dukes of Urbin, like them of Ferrara, of Mantua, and of Florence, contributed to the revival of the Arts of De≈øigning. For Jerom Genga, an Excellent Painter, was in great favour with the≈øe Dukes. He had ≈øtudied under Peter Perugino with Raphael Urbin, his Illu≈øtrious Countryman; he practi≈øed al≈øo Architecture, and the Duke Guido-baldo employ'd him to build, and paint his Palaces of Urbin and Pi≈øaro, and to fortify this la≈øt City. Bartholomew, the Son of Genga, was al≈øo an Architect and Engineer, as well as his Father.

argument.p: Painting continued in its Beauty at Venice, as did al≈øo Architecture at Venice and Rome.

div.p:
AT Venice the excellency of Painting did not decline during the whole la≈øt Age. The Famous Paul Verone≈øe
Paul Callieri was born at Verona in 1532, his Father was a Sculptor, who taught him from his Youth to De≈øign and Model; but as he had a greater Inclination to Painting, he put him to Anthony Badile his Uncle, who was one of the be≈øt Painters of Verona, in a ≈øhort time Paul became very skilful, after which he went and work'd at Mantua with Paul Farinati, Dominick Bru≈øa≈øorci, and Bapti≈øia del Moro all of them Young Painters of Verona, whom the Cardinal Hercules cau≈øed to come thither to Paint the Chappel of the Cathedral. After Paul had painted ≈øeveral Pieces at Verona and in ≈øeveral Cities of the Venetian State, he ≈øettled him≈øelf at Venice, where his Works gain'd an univer≈øal Applau≈øe and E≈øteem. James Robu≈øti called Tintorett, was born at Venice in 1512; from his Childhood he took to De≈øigning on the Walls, and afterwards colouring his Figures with Diers Colours, for his Father was a Dyer, who ≈øeeing the inclination of his Son put him to Titian, where he remain'd but a ≈øhort time: Afterwards he ≈øtudied De≈øigning of him≈øelf, after the Way of Michael Angelo, and the Manner of Colouring of Titian, which he joined with the ob≈øervation of Nature, and formed after this manner his fine manner of Painting, and filied Venice with his admirable Pictures; he died in 1594. Tintoret, continued to embelli≈øh the Palaces and Churches of that City and of the Venetian State with a great Number of excellent Pieces: In≈øomuch that the≈øe Pieces both then and ≈øtill cau≈øe admiration in the Curious, and ≈øerve for Examples of Study to young Painters, who love this fine Way of Painting and Colouring. Jerom Mutiano of Bre≈øcia, was al≈øo of this State and learnt the Principles of Painting: Afterwards he perfected him≈øelf at Venice by the Pieces of Titian, where he learn'd the true Way of Colouring, and drawing Landskips, wherein he was Excellent. After this he went to Rome, where he continued to Study his Art with ≈øo much Ardor, that to beat Love out of his Head, which he found ≈øomewhat to hinder him, he cut off his Hair, and never ≈øtirr'd from home, till his Picture of the Re≈øurrection of Lazarus was done, and his Hair grown again.
