He work'd for the Cardinal d'E≈øte, who had a very great E≈øteem for him; he made ≈øeveral other Pictures at Rome, at Orvieta and at Loretto. Among the other good Qualities of Mutiano, he had an extraordinary Way of teaching Youth, and by his Will he left two Hou≈øes to the Academy of St. Luke, and al≈øo ≈øomething to build Apartments for the Students of De≈øigning who were Poor; it was he who by his Credit with Pope Gregrory the XIIIth, obtained a Brief of him to found that Academy, and who cau≈øed the demoli≈øh'd Church of St. Luke on the Mount E≈øquilino to be changed into that of St. Martin, which ≈øtood at the Foot of the Capitol, and which has been ≈øince rebuilt, and embelli≈øh'd according to the De≈øigning of Pietro da Cortona a famous Painter of this Age.

Architecture, which had been brought to a very high Degree of Perfection at Venice, by the famous Architects we have mentioned, was continued there after the true and fine Way of the Antients, by Daniel Barbaro, Scammozzi, and Andrew Palladio, who excell'd the others, as the fine Churches he built at Venice ≈øufficiently te≈øtify; as al≈øo the Palaces and Seats of Plea≈øure and other Buildings he made in the Venetian State; which are all of a true and fine Way. This Art
Among the be≈øt Architects of the la≈øt Age, who preceeded the≈øe la≈øt of all, and were contemporary with Michael Angelo, may be reckoned the two Brothers Julian and Anthony da ≈øan Gallo of Florence. Naples and Rome, and all the Provinces where there were any of tho≈øe Old Buildings, or any Fragments of them remaining.

This great Man James Barozzi da Vignola went when he was Young to Bologna there to learn Painting, but finding that for want of Means and In≈øtruction, he did not much profit therein; he re≈øolved to ≈øet him≈øelf wholly to ≈øtudy Architecture, for his inclination led him mo≈øt that Way: He had al≈øo a particular Fancy for Per≈øpective, wherein he found out by his Study tho≈øe fine Rules he publi≈øhed.

div.head: CHAP. XX.

argument.p: The Arts of De≈øigning flouri≈øh'd in France under Francis the I≈øt, and Henry the IId, and their Succe≈ø≈øors.

div.p: BY what we have ≈øaid of Vignola, it may be gathered that the true manner of Architecture began to revive in France, and even before his time, for it began under Lewis the XIIth, who cau≈øed Jocondo to come out of Italy. King Francis his Succe≈ø≈øor had the like Inclination not only for Architecture, but al≈øo for This great Prince was ≈øo great a Lover of the≈øe Arts, that he made it one of his Recreations to De≈øign and Paint. Painting and for all the other Arts of De≈øigning. For he ≈øent for ≈øeveral Ingenious Italians into France, to whom he ≈øhewed particular Favours. Ro≈ø≈øo, known in France by the Name of Roux, was among the chiefe≈øt of his Favourites. He was a Painter and Architect, of a good Mein, and very Ingenious. This excellent Genius apply'd him≈øelf in his Youth at Florence to ≈øtudy the great Piece done by Michael Angelo in the Council-Hall: Afterwards he painted of him≈øelf, without following any Ma≈øter.

Afterwards he went into France where he was ≈øo happy as to get the Favour and Affection of
the King, who allow'd him a Pen≈øion of four hundred Crowns. After that he began to Paint the lower Gallery at Fountainbleau, where he painted twenty four Hi≈øtorical Pieces of Alexander the Great: This plea≈øed the King ≈øo much that he gave him a Canon≈øhip in the Chappel at Paris.

Ro≈ø≈øo moreover painted ≈øeveral Chambers at Fountainbleau, which after his Death were ≈øomewhat changed: There was a Book of ≈øeveral De≈øigns of Anatomy which he had made for the King, about to be engraved
Le Roux, whom the Italians call il Ro≈ø≈øo, a Florentine Painter and Architect, died at Paris in 1541 of a Melancholy, which he conceived by having incon≈øiderately accu≈øed one of his be≈øt Friends of having robbed him. The King and all that knew him were very ≈øorrowful for his Death. His Di≈øciples and tho≈øe who work'd for him in Painting and Plai≈øter were Naldino a Florentine, Ma≈øter Francis of Orleans, Claudius of Paris, Laurence Picard and ≈øeveral others, the mo≈øt Ingenious whereof was Dominick del Barbieri a Florentine, an excellent Painter and Arti≈øt in Stucco-work, and al≈øo a good De≈øigner, as is to be ≈øeen by his Stamps., but was prevented by the decea≈øe of this Painter.

Francis Primaticcio of Bolonia carried on the Works of Ro≈ø≈øo at Fountainbleau: He came into France in the Year 1531, a year after the E≈øtabli≈øhment of Ro≈ø≈øo: That which cau≈øed this Voyage of Primaticcio, was that the King had heard of the Beauty of the Painting and Stucco-work, wherewith the famous Julio Romano had adorn'd the Palace of T. at Mantua. Primaticcio had been ≈øix Years a Di≈øciple of Julio Romano, and had di≈øtingui≈øh'd him≈øelf by the Beauty of the Stucco-work he made, by the ea≈øine≈øs of his De≈øigning, and by the way he had of managing Colours in Fre≈øco. This Painter was cho≈øen out by the Duke of Mantua for Francis the I.
who ≈øet him to Paint in Fre≈øco, and work in Stucco, which had not till then been ≈øeen in France, and after having had the Honour to ≈øerve the King eight Years, his Maje≈øty honoured him with the Charge of a Valet of his Chamber, and afterwards he was rewarded with the Abby of St. Martin de Troie, whereof Primaticcio a≈ø≈øumed the Name.

The Works which this illu≈øtrious
Primaticcio Abbot of St. Martin had ≈øeveral Di≈øciples: The mo≈øt Ingenious was Nicolo of Modena, known in France under the Name of Me≈ø≈øer Nicolo; he painted in Fre≈øco the Gallery of Uly≈ø≈øes at Fountainbleau; he al≈øo made ≈øeveral other Pieces in Fre≈øco there. There are ≈øome Pieces of his Painting to be yet ≈øeen at Beauregar near Blois, and in ≈øeveral Places in France. Per≈øon made at Meudon in Architecture, in Sculpture and in Painting, are no le≈øs agreeable than tho≈øe he made in the Gallery and Apartments which he painted at Fountainbleau; and be≈øides the excellent Genius he had for the≈øe Arts, he was extraordinary for inventing fe≈øtival Decorations and ≈øuch like Ornaments, which he did at Court on ≈øeveral Occa≈øions.
Primaticcio made Abbot of St. Martin, continued to ≈øerve the Succe≈ø≈øor of Francis the I≈øt, in quality of Painter, Architect, and Valet de Chamber to the King.

Under Francis the IId, he was made The Abbot of St. Martin was made Surveyor of the Kings Buildings, and his chief Architect, in 1559 in room of Philbert de Lorme, whom he ≈øucceeded in all his Charges. Surveyor General of the Buildings for his Maje≈øty. That Charge had been executed before by the Father of Cardinal de la Bourdai≈øiere, and Mon≈øieur de Villeroy.

After the Death of Francis the IId; the Abbot of St. Martin continued his Charge of Surveyor
General of the Buildings, and by the Order of Katharine de Medicis he made at St. Dennis the Tomb of the Valois: And although that Work remained Imperfect, yet there are to be ≈øeen repre≈øented on Ba≈øs Reliefs the Battles of Francis the I≈øt, which are of an incomparable De≈øign, and very ingeniou≈øly managed according to the Art of Sculpture in the nice Gradations of the Groups of Figures, which appear one ≈øtanding out before the other.

This makes it appear, that it was under the Reigns of the≈øe Princes, and this Prince≈øs that the Arts of De≈øigning were Re-e≈øtabli≈øhed in France, and flouri≈øh'd there: For be≈øides the ingenious Italians who labour'd in their Revival, the French Nation ≈øet them≈øelves with great Succe≈øs to Architecture and Sculpture; thus the Abbot of Clagni apply'd him≈øelf to the Management of the Building of the Louvre, after Henry the IId had began it. The two du Cerceaux were ingenious Architects, as al≈øo Philbert de Lorme and John Bullant
Le Primaticcio Abbot of St. Martin died about 1570. The King put in his Place John Bullant to be Architect at Fountainbleau. See Telibien, Of the Works of the Painters, p. 705.
From the time of Primaticcio, the true Way in the Arts of De≈øigning began to ≈øpread in France, even to painting on Gla≈øs; for that rea≈øon we ≈øee ≈øeveral of that time that are very extraordinary; as al≈øo ≈øeveral Works in Enamel, whereof there are ≈øeveral Pieces which adorn the two Altars in the Chappel of Paris, the De≈øignment whereof is very admirable and altogether after the Way of Julio Romano and Primaticcio: There are al≈øo ≈øeveral earthen Ve≈ø≈øels of that Work painted and enamell'd, which were made in France as well as in Italy. The Abbot of Saint Martin made ≈øeveral De≈øignments in Tapi≈øtry, ≈øome whereof are to be ≈øeen in Hangings in the Palace of Conde, and other Princes.
Among the good Architects of that time may be numbred E≈øtienne de Perac, who had the Honour to be Architect and Painter to the King. He painted at Fountainbleau the Hall of the Baths, and died in 1600. F. P. 712. , who all of them gave proofs of
their Skill by the Buildings they erected, and the Books of Architecture which they publi≈øhed.

Moreover the Illu≈øtrious John Gonjou was Excellent in Architecture and Sculpture: He gave Proofs thereof in his Works at the Louvre, at St. German de L' Auxerrois, at the Fountain of St. Innocent and other Buildings, whereby he ≈øhewed him≈øelf a good Architect and excellent Sculptor. About this time there appeared other excellent Sculptors, as Ponce and Bartelemi, who were fellow Students at Rome.

But among all the Sculptors, the mo≈øt remarkable was James
Vigenerus on the Tablets of Philo≈øtratus, P. 855. Relates that this happened at Rome in 1550. when he was there. He takes notice that this ingenious Sculptor made three great Figures of black Wax, which for their Excellence are kept in the Vatican; the one repre≈øents a naked Man to the Life; the other one in the ≈øame Po≈øture without his Skin, where one may di≈øtinctly ≈øee the Origine and In≈øertions of the Mu≈øcles; and the third is almo≈øt a Skeleton.
The ≈øame Author tells us further, of a fine Marble Figure repre≈øenting Autumn, which was in the Grotto of Meudon; he ≈øays, that he ≈øaw it, and that it was made at Rome: It is very Excellent, and as much E≈øteemed as any modern Piece, which ≈øhews the Excellency of this Sculptor. d'Angoul√™me, who was ≈øo skilful as to Rival Michael Angelo in a Model of St. Peter's, and who in the Judgment even of the Italians ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed therein this great Man. About the ≈øame time Pilon There is to be ≈øeen of Pilon's a St. Francis in the Cloy≈øter of the Augu≈øtines, and at St. Katharines a Chappel where there are fine Figures and Ba≈øs Reliefs in Bra≈øs, and in ≈øeveral other Churches, and on the Dial of the Palace there are ≈øome of his Works. al≈øo di≈øtingui≈øh'd him≈øelf at Paris by the excellent Pieces of Engraving which he made in ≈øeveral Churches and other publick Places. Thus France produced in the la≈øt Age excellent Architects and Sculptors: She had al≈øo ≈øome famous Painters, and among the re≈øt
John Cou≈øin who flouri≈øh'd under Henry the IId, Francis the IId, Charles the IXth and Henry the IIId: The Picture which is to be ≈øeen of his of the General Judgment, among the Minims at St. Vincent, which was very well graved by Peter Jode, ≈øhews the Excellence of his De≈øigning and Pencil, as al≈øo the ≈øeveral Gla≈ø≈øes he has painted at St. Gervais in Paris, ≈øhew that he was Ma≈øter of ≈øeveral Arts that relate to De≈øigning.

He was al≈øo an excellent Sculptor, as may be ≈øeen on the Sepulcher of the Admiral Chabot, which is done by him in the Chappel of Orleans at Paris; and the Treati≈øes he has made of Geometry and Per≈øpective ≈øufficiently ≈øhew the Greatne≈øs and extent of his Genius.

Several other French Painters got a great deal of Reputation about the End of the la≈øt Age at Fountainbleau, the be≈øt of them were Ferminet, du Brevil, and Bunel
Jacob Bunel went into Spain, where he copied the Pictures of Titian; afterwards he went to Rome where he ≈øtudied in the School of Frederico Zucchero, to perfect him≈øelf in De≈øigning and Painting. who ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed them all; this la≈øt was named Jacob, he was born at Blois in 1558, Son of Francis Bunel Painter, under whom he learnt the Principles of Painting: After he had perfected him≈øelf in Italy, he gave Proofs of his Skill in the Works he made for the King in the little Gallery of the Lowvre The≈øe Works were de≈øtroy'd by a Fire which happen'd in the Gallery of the Louvre in 1660. There is al≈øo to be ≈øeen of Bunel's, the Picture of the great Altar of the Mendicant Friers at Paris, and al≈øo in the Church of St. Severin ≈øeveral Figures of the Prophets, the Sibils, and of the Apo≈øtles painted on a gold-Ground: There is al≈øo to be ≈øeen at Blois in the Quire of the Capuchins, a Picture which he painted of an excellent Beauty. See the Hi≈øtory of Blois by Bernier, P. 521., which he painted together with Brevil. This al≈øo appear'd
in the Tuilleries, and in the Picture of the De≈øcent of the Holy Gho≈øt, in the Church of the Augu≈øtins at Paris: The Excellence of this Picture gain'd him the Approbation of the illu≈øtrious Pou≈ø≈øin, who a≈ø≈øures us, that of all the Pieces in that City, there was not one that equall'd this.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.

argument.p: The Flemings perfected them≈øelves in Painting, after they had found the Invention of Painting in Oyl.

div.p: PAINTING in the two la≈øt Ages made a great Progre≈øs in Flanders: And the Flemings cultivated it with a great deal of Care: For after John of Bruges had found out the Way of Painting in Oyl, in 1410, he brought up ≈øeveral Di≈øciples, and among the re≈øt Roger Vanderverden of Brue≈ø≈øels, and Have≈ø≈øe who taught this fine Secret to Lewis of Louvain.

Peter Cri≈øto, Ju≈øtus of Ghent, Hugo of Antwerp appear'd ≈øome time after: They work'd only in the low Countries with Reputation, about the End of 1400, and at the beginning of 1500. In the la≈øt of the≈øe Centuries ≈øeveral other Painters of that Nation began to make them≈øelves known: Lambert Lombard was at Liege of the fir≈øt Rank for Painting and Architecture. He there brought up ≈øome excellent Di≈øciples; the mo≈øt Famous was Francis Florus, who is looked upon as the Raphael of the Flemi≈øh, by rea≈øon of his true Way of De≈øigning: William Cay of Breda was al≈øo a Di≈øciple of Lambert Lombard, he
pa≈ø≈øed for a very good Painter: There was not in his Works that Fire, and Re≈øolution to be ≈øeen as in tho≈øe of Francis Florus, but there appeared more of the Life, and of Sweetne≈øs and good Grace. There were about that time ≈øeveral Flemi≈øh Ma≈øters al≈øo who gain'd Reputation in Italy, both by Painting and Architecture; Michael Cocki≈øian was one of them, it was he who painted the two Chappels in Fre≈øco in 1522 in the Church dell'Anima, after the Italian Way. There was al≈øo John de Calker who ought to be e≈øteemed for his Manner of Painting and De≈øigning: He learnt of the Famous Titian, and de≈øigned ≈øome excellent Stamps and Plates of Anatomy, which made the Book of Andrew Ve≈øalius ≈øo Famous.

Heemskirk, Martin de Vos, and John Strada ≈øtudiin Italy the true Manner of De≈øigning and Painting: Strada made ≈øeveral Pieces at Florence for the Great Duke, particularly ≈øeveral Patterns for Tapi≈øtry, whereby he ≈øhewed that he had an univer≈øal Genius in all the different Parts of Painting; his great Capacity procur'd him admittance into the Academy of De≈øigning.

The low Countries produced ≈øeveral other Painters; Divic, and Quintin of
Va≈øari ≈øays, that Quintin was of Louvain: But A. F. thinks he was of Antwerp, who, from a good Black≈ømith and Farrier, became a good Painter, through the natural Inclination he had from his Youth for De≈øigning, and the great Pa≈ø≈øion he entertain'd for a Young Woman, who promi≈øed him Marriage on Condition he became a good Painter: This encouraged him to learn Painting, which he very ≈øucce≈øsfully accompli≈øh'd. Louvain were very much e≈øteemed for their true Imitation of Nature. John deCleves was excellent in Colouring and drawing Portraits: In≈øomuch that Francis the I≈øt took him into his Service, during which time he drew a great many of the Lords and Ladies of the Court.

In the ≈øame Provinces were John d' Hemei≈ø≈øein,
Martin Cook, John Cornelis, and Lambert Scoorel, who was a Canon at Utrecht: John belle Jambe, Divick d' Harlem and Francis Mon≈øtaret, were Excellent in Landskips, and odd Fanta≈øtick Figures. This la≈øt was imitated by Jerome Hertoghen Bos, Peter Brueghel and Lancelot, who was very Excellent at painting Fires.

In the≈øe Countries was al≈øo Peter Cocuek, who had a great facility and readine≈øs of Invention, for he made ≈øeveral very fine Hi≈øtorical De≈øigns for Tapi≈øtry; he had a very good Way, and a great deal of practice in Architecture, which made him tran≈ølate the Books of Serlio into Dutch. But he who of all the Painters of the Low Countries ought to be the mo≈øt e≈øteemed was Anthony More Painter to Philip the IId King of Spain: The Pictures and Portraits which are to be ≈øeen of this famous Painters Hand will always make him pa≈øs for an excellent Per≈øon; he learnt Painting of Lambert Scoorel.

Several ≈øpeak al≈øo with a great deal of Prai≈øe of Peter Le Long, who made at Am≈øterdam, where he was born, a Picture of the Virgin with other Saints for which he had two thou≈øand Crowns. Mathew and Paul Bril were at that time very Famous for making Landskips; they wrought a long time at Rome; and in Flanders there appear'd with a very great Reputation Octavius Vanveen, who is al≈øo called Otto-Venius. He was Painter to the Duke of Parma, who was Governour of the Low Countries, and afterwards to the Arch Duke Albert. It was he who was Ma≈øter of the Famous Paul Rubens.

Peter Porbus of Bruges was al≈øo a Painter; he taught Francis his Son to Paint, who continued to learn under Francis Florus; this la≈øt had a Son called Francis, who wrought at Paris in the Church
of St. Leu of the reformed Jacobins, and in the Stadt-Hou≈øe, where he ≈øhewed his great Capacity.

At the ≈øame time Sculpture flouri≈øh'd in the Low Countries as well as Painting, for tho≈øe two Noble Exerci≈øes are Originated from the ≈øame Principle, which is De≈øigning: For this rea≈øon there were bred in that Country excellent Sculptors; as William of Antwerp, John de Dales, William Cucur of Holland, and James Bru≈øca, all Sculptors and Architects. Bru≈øca made ≈øeveral Pieces for the Queen of Hungary, and he brought up John Bologna of Douay.

It was this Famous John Bologna, who gain'd the mo≈øt Honour of any to his Nation for Sculpture, by the Beauty which appear'd in all his Works, which have all of them the true Way and Gu≈øt of the Ancients, wherein he perfected him≈øelf in Italy, and particularly at Florence, where he re≈øided, and held the fir≈øt Place in that Art. He was there employ'd by the Princes de Medicis to make ≈øeveral Pieces of Sculpture: The fine Marble Statues, and the great Groupes of Figures in Bra≈øs which adorn the Squares of Florence, of Leghorn, and of Bologna are very charming, and ≈øo many proofs of his Excellence, and Monuments of his Glory.

There are yet at Paris ≈øome Marks remaining of the Excellence of his Workman≈øhip, as the Brazen Hor≈øe whereon is the Figure of Henry the IVth in the Square of Pont-neuf: Thus we may ≈øee that both in the Low Countries, and in France as well as Italy, the Arts of De≈øigning had their Revival by the Means and Ways we have ≈øhewn. That which farther contributed towards it, was the Genius and Application of ≈øeveral Ingenious Painters, Sculptors and Architects who flouri≈øh'd in the Centuries 1400 and 1500.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.

p.hi: How Graving contributed towards the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the Arts of De≈øigning.

div.p: TO fini≈øh this la≈øt Book, it remains that we ≈øhew the Advantage which the Arts of De≈øigning received by the Invention of Graving, which was found out at Florence in 1460; for this Invention was, and is very ≈øerviceable to bring tho≈øe Arts to Perfection.

It is certain that the Way of De≈øigning on Copper, with the Tools called the Burin and Point, was one of the happy Means for the Revival of the Arts: For Graving multiplies and imparts Copies of the De≈øigns, and fine Ideas of Excellent Painters, Sculptors and Architects; in≈øomuch that the Prints which are taken off from the≈øe Graved Plates; were of excellent U≈øe in the Revival of De≈øigning, in ≈øeveral Countries, which have not had the Advantage, like Italy, of fine Examples of the Ancient Architecture and Sculpture, and the Works of the mo≈øt excellent Modern Painters and Sculptors, which are happily communicated by the Help of Copper-Plates.

This has been, and is ≈øtill ≈øeen in France, and other Places, that the fine Books of Architecture have made a great many Good Architects; who without going to Italy, where are the fine Relicks of Antiquity, have formed a true and good Manner, and perfected their Studies in this Art by the Help of Graving, which faithfully repre≈øents the Plans, Profils, the Elevations and Mea≈øures of the fine≈øt Buildings.

Painting has al≈øo the ≈øame Advantage by Prints as Architecture, and has given that way ≈øolid In≈øtructions to ≈øeveral Painters. This may
be remarked by the Prints of Mark Antonio graved after the De≈øigns of Raphael, which have taught the true manner of De≈øigning to ≈øeveral very con≈øiderable Painters.

The Illu≈øtrious Pou≈ø≈øin is an Example of this, in the great Application he made in his Youth to De≈øign by tho≈øe Prints when he was at Paris. It was here this Great Painter ≈øo happily imitated the manner of Raphael, and the Ancients, in his admirable Works.

The Sculptors moreover received the ≈øame advantage from Graving as the Painters, for that made the De≈øigns of the fine Figures of the Ancients familiar to them, and all the fine Ba≈øs Reliefs of the Famous Columns and Triumphal Arches, which are to be ≈øeen in the Palaces and Hou≈øes of Rome.

Graving was found out at Florence by Ma≈øo Fineguerra a Gold≈ømith, who printed all that he grav'd on Silver: Afterwards Baccio Bandinelli, who was a Florentine Gold≈ømith, continued that Art, but as he was no good De≈øigner, he copied the De≈øigns of Sandro Boticelli of that City. The Invention of Graving, being then come to the knowledge of Andrew Mantegna, an Excellent Painter, who was about that time at Rome, he was ≈øo much enamour'd with it, that he ≈øet him≈øelf to learn it, and he graved Bacchanalians with the Burin, and a great Triumph he cut in Wood, which was very Admirable. This Art went afterwards from Italy into the Low Countries: Martin of Antwerp who was a Painter, practi≈øed it, and ≈øent a great many of his Plates into Italy, and continued to make them better and better.

After Martin of Antwerp, Albert Durer, in the ≈øame City began to Grave after a better Manner, De≈øign and Compo≈øition; for he endeavour'd more
nearly to follow Nature, and approach the Italian way, which he always e≈øteemed the be≈øt: About the Year 1503, he made a ≈ømall Statue of the Virgin, which ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed the Works of Martin of Antwerp, and he continued to make ≈øeveral Plates of Hor≈øes, de≈øign'd according to Nature, with anothere of the Prodigal Son.

But when he had graved ≈øeveral of the≈øe Plates with the Burin, and ≈øaw, that they took up a great deal of Time, he ≈øet him≈øelf to Grave on Wood, that he might publi≈øh a greater Number of his Works, and in the Year 1510 he publi≈øhed of that Sort of Graving the beheading of St. John, the Pa≈ø≈øion of our Lord, and ≈øeveral other Pieces which went quickly off. Albert, by the e≈øteem People ≈øet on his Works, became very Rich; and this engaged him to Grave again with the Burin, and he made a Piece repre≈øenting Melancholy, three Notre Dames, with the Pa≈ø≈øion of our Lord in thirty ≈øix Pieces.

About this time Francis Francia was e≈øteemed at Bologna of the fir≈øt rank of Painters; he had ≈øeveral Di≈øciples, whereof Mark-Antonio Raimondi was the be≈øt, by rea≈øon of his Capacity in De≈øigning, which gave him a great Facility in handling the Burin in Gold≈ømiths Works, in which he was Excellent. But according to a Re≈øolution he took to Travel, he went to Venice. There he ≈øaw Stamps which Albert had made with the Burin, and in Wood. They ≈øo plea≈øed him that he bought of them as far as his Money would reach; among the re≈øt he had the Pa≈ø≈øion cut in Wood: And after reflecting what Honour and Profit he ≈øhould have gotten, if he had employ'd him≈øelf to Grave after that way, he at length determined to ≈øet him≈øelf wholly thereunto, and he ≈øo well copied that Pa≈ø≈øion of Albert's on Copper, that it was
taken to have been done on Wood; he al≈øo put the Mark of Albert A. D. thereon, and ≈øo well imitated that Work, that no body took it for Mark-Antonio's but for Albert's, and it was bought and ≈øold for ≈øuch at Venice; in≈øomuch that ≈øome Copies were ≈øent to Albert of the Pa≈ø≈øion that Mark-Antonio had done, which made Albert ≈øo very angry, that he went from Antwerp to Venice to complain to the Republick of the Wrongs Mark-Antonio had done him: But he could obtain nothing thereby, but only that his Mark ≈øhould be no more put to Mark-Antonio's Pieces.

Albert at his Return to Antwerp found a Competitor, Lucas van Leyden, who
Lucas van Leyden had an extraordinary Inclination for De≈øigning even in his Childhood; he made Pictures at the Age of twelve Years; he apply'd him≈øelf al≈øo to Graving; at fifteen Years of Age he had grav'd ≈øeveral Copper Plates; he died at thirty nine. Years of Age in 1533. In the time of Lucas and Albert, there appeared with a great deal of Reputation Han Holbein of Ba≈øil. He practi≈øed al≈øo Graving; there are of his Hand Wooden Cuts of the Bible, and a Dance of the Dead, which he painted in that City. But his chief Occupation was Painting, which he practi≈øed a long time in England, where he was e≈øteemed the mo≈øt Ingenious of his Time; he died at fifty ≈øix Years of Age in 1554. though he was not ≈øo good a De≈øigner as him≈øelf, he notwith≈øtanding equall'd him in the Beauty of working with his Burin, as he made it appear in 1509, by two round Prints; the one was Chri≈øt carrying his Cro≈øs, the other his Crucifixion.
Lucas continued to ≈øhew his Ingenuity, by a Pa≈ø≈øion, which he grav'd in ≈øixteen Pieces, and by his other Works.

Albert, at this, grew jealous of Lucas's Knowledge; and becau≈øe he would not be excell'd, he redoubled his Application and Indu≈øtry in Graving. He made ≈øeveral fine Prints, as St. Eu≈øtachius,
St. Jerom, and ≈øeveral others, which augmented his Reputation: For he was not only a good Graver, but al≈øo a good Painter, Geometrician and Architect.

This may be ≈øeen by his Treati≈øe of the Proportions of an human Figure, of Per≈øpective and Architecture: His Works have made his Name
Albert Durer died at Nuremberg, his own Country, in 1528, at fifty eight Years of Age. This Epitaph is to be read on his Tomb. Quicquid Alberti Dureri mortale fuit, conditur hoc tumulo. Emigravit VIII Idus Aprilis, 1528.
This ingenious Man was very much honoured by the Emperors Maximilian, Charles the V. and Ferdinand King of Hungary. One of his Di≈øciples was Aldegrave a Painter and Graver at Nuremberg.
Illu≈øtrious, for they contributed to the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of the Arts in Flanders and Germany, and al≈øo in Italy; for they were the Prints of Albert which engaged Mark-Antonio to follow Graving, and made him Grave ≈øo happily the Works of Raphael, that are ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to all De≈øigners.

Thus by the Opportunity Mark-Antonio had of Copying at Venice the Prints of Albert, he acquired a facility and readine≈øs in Graving, and went afterwards to Rome, where the fir≈øt Thing he grav'd was a Lucretia, after Raphael: This was ≈øhewn to this great Painter, who at the ≈øame time contracted a Friend≈øhip with Mark-Anthonio, and ≈øet him to Grave a Plate of the Judgment of Paris, another of the Death of the Innocents, and ≈øeveral others.

This was very Advantageous to Raphael, and gained him, as well as Mark-Antonio, a great Reputation throughout all Europe, and created an Emulation among ≈øeveral De≈øigners, who apply'd them≈øelves to Graving, and became Di≈øciples of Mark-Antonio.
The mo≈øt Ingenious were Mark de Ravenna and Augu≈øtin Venetianus, who grav'd ≈øeveral De≈øigns of Raphael and Julio Romano.

Mark-Antonio after the Death of Raphael, graved the De≈øigns of Julio Romano, which are ob≈øcene Po≈øtures, for which he was arre≈øted at Rome, and as he e≈øcaped from Pri≈øon, he went to Florence, where he fini≈øh'd his Plate of St. Laurence, after the De≈øign of Baccio Bandinclli. In the mean while Baccio complain'd to Pope Clement the VIIth that Mark-Antonio ≈øpoil'd, in≈øtead of imitating, his De≈øigns: This came to his Knowledge, and after his Prints were fini≈øhed, he carried them to this Pope, together with the De≈øigns of Bandinelli, and as his Holine≈øs was very Skilful in, and a great Lover of De≈øigning, he judged quite otherwi≈øe, and acknowledged, that this ingenious Graver had very much mended the Faults that were in the De≈øigning of Bandinelli. In≈øomuch that by the Beauty of that rare Print, Mark-Antonio regain'd the Favour of this Pope, which the Po≈øtures of Aretin had unhappily cau≈øed him to lo≈øe.

But about this time happened the ≈øacking and taking of Rome, which reduced Mark-Antonio almo≈øt to Beggary. For to redeem him≈øelf out of the Hands of the Imperiali≈øts who had made him Pri≈øoner, he was oblig'd to give them all the Money he had, and ≈øo went from Rome, whither he returned no more.

About this time was found out the way of Graving in Wood with Chiaro-≈øcuro, which make the Prints appear as if they were heightened with White by the Pencil; and the Per≈øon who found out this Invention was Hugo de Carpi, an indifferently good Painter, but who had a Genius for ≈øeveral Things. There are ≈øome
of the≈øe ≈øorts of Prints after Raphael, of Parmegiano, of Balda≈ø≈øare and of Beccafumi, and others.

The way of Etching with Aqua-fortis began al≈øo to be practi≈øed about this Time, by Parmegiano and Beccafumi, who etch'd ≈øeveral Plates. After them Bapti≈øta del Moro a Painter of Verona etch'd with Aqua-fortis fifty fine Landskips. He was a Di≈øciple of Titian, and would have been one of the mo≈øt Famous of his Age, if he had not died before he was thirty Years of Age.

Jerome Cock, Graved in Flanders the ≈øeven liberal Arts, and at Rome ≈øeveral Prints after the De≈øigns of Seba≈øtian Frate del Piombo, and after tho≈øe of Francis Salviati. At Venice, Bapti≈øta Franco an ingenious Painter graved ≈øeveral of his Works. In the mean while Graving continued at Rome by James Caraglio of Verona, whom Ro≈ø≈øo the Painter cau≈øed to Grave ≈øeveral Prints after his De≈øigns; he al≈øo Graved ≈øome more after Perin del Vaga, Parmegiano and Titian: But Caraglio after he had thus wrought, ≈øet him≈øelf to Grave on Cry≈øtals and Cornelian, wherein he had no le≈øs ≈øucce≈øs than on Copper; and the King of Poland ≈øent for him to Work in Graving and Architecture, which he ≈øucce≈øsfully practi≈øed in that Kingdom.

John Bapti≈øta Mantuano of the School of Julio Romano, apply'd him≈øelf to Graving with the Burin, and made ≈øome fine Prints after the Works of his Ma≈øter, which are very much e≈øteem'd; there are to be ≈øeen ≈øome Prints done by his Daughter Diana, which are well grav'd.

Aeneas Vico of Parma, was al≈øo a Graver and wrought with the Burin; he copied the De≈øigns of Ro≈ø≈øo, of Michael Angelo, of Titian, of Salviati, and of Bandinelli, and grav'd ≈øeveral Portraits; That of Charles the V. enriched with Trophies
(by which he got a great deal of Prai≈øe, and a large Reward,) is one of the mo≈øt con≈øiderable of his Works.
At Rome Nicholas Beatrix Lorain continued this Art; he work'd after Mutian, after Michael Angelo, and after Ghiotto the Boat of St. Peter, with ≈øeveral other Prints, very much e≈øteemed.

There were other Italian Gravers who di≈øtingui≈øh'd them≈øelves by their Prints at Rome, as Cherubin Albert, who grav'd the fine Frizes after Polydore: And al≈øo Vilamen d'A≈ø≈øi≈øe for the correctne≈øs of his De≈øigning and the liberty of his Burin. The ≈øame E≈øteem is due to Antony l'Abacco, who mea≈øured and graved a Book of the ancient Buildings, which is one of the mo≈øt regular Pieces of Architecture that has been publi≈øhed.

There were ≈øeveral other ingenious Engravers in the Low Countries; Hubert Goltius of Venlo was there Famous. He learnt Painting of Lambert Lombard, afterwards he graved ≈øeveral Books of Medals of the Emperors, entituled Fa≈øti, and Sicilia, and Magna Grecia, and others, of which al≈øo he compo≈øed a Di≈øcour≈øe in Latin, and becau≈øe he was very well ver≈øed in Hi≈øtory, he was honoured with the Quality of Hi≈øtorian and Painter to Philip the IId. He died at Bruges in 1583. Of the ≈øame Family of Goltius was al≈øo Henry, who employ'd him≈øelf much in Graving and Painting, having made two Voyages into Italy, to perfect him≈øelf; be≈øides his Ingenuity in Painting and Graving, he De≈øigned incomparably well with his Pen. He was born at Venlo in 1558. Saenredam, Matam and Peter Jode, were his Di≈øciples.

Cornelius Cort, and Martin Rota, ≈øhewed their Capacity by ≈øome Pieces they grav'd after Michael Angelo, Mutian and others, as al≈øo John, Raphael and Giles Sadeler, who were of Bru≈ø≈øels, promoted
very much the Art of Graving, by the Beauty of their Prints. Collaert, Philip and Cornelius Gall of the ≈øame Country grav'd there, and afterwards in Italy, with a great deal of Reputaion.
This Art appear'd al≈øo in great Splendour in France in the time of Ro≈ø≈øo, and of the Abbot St. Martin; for Ren√®, engraved the mo≈øt Part of their Works, which are at Fountainbleau.
In≈øomuch that in all the Countries where the Arts of De≈øigning flouri≈øhed, Graving flouri≈øh'd al≈øo, and was e≈øteemed as a con≈øiderable Part of tho≈øe Arts.

But the Per≈øon who mo≈øt advanced Graving about the End of the la≈øt Age, and improved it beyond what had been till then done, was the Famous Augu≈øtin Carrache: For, not to mention the Correctne≈øs and excellent manner of De≈øigning he was Ma≈øter of, to a very high Degree, he made the Strokes cut with his Burin extreme even, and extraordinarily well managed according to the chief Turns and Forms of his Object, even to Landskips, which he touch'd incomparably well.

From his Youth he learnt Painting at Bologna of Pro≈øper Fontana, afterwards he ≈øtudied Graving and Architecture under Dominick Tibaldi. In a ≈øhort time he exceeded his Ma≈øter, who got con≈øiderably by the Ingenuity of his Di≈øciple. Augu≈øtin had al≈øo a great Love for Sculpture, which made him work in Relievo under Alexander Minganti a Bolonian. Notwith≈øtanding which he did not leave off Graving, for he had a general Genius, which led him to Learning, to Geometry, and all its dependencies.

He went afterwards with his Brother, the Famous Hannibal Carrache to ≈øtudy Painting in Lombardy, and to learn the charming fine Manner of
Painting of Correggio: But he left his Brother at Parma, and went him≈øelf to Venice, where he employ'd him≈øelf in graving the Pictures of Tintoret and Paul Verone≈øe, and thereby render'd their Works more Famous, by the Beauty of his De≈øigning, which made his Prints more perfect than tho≈øe of other Gravers. He moreover grav'd ≈øeveral Pieces after Correggio, after Baroche, and made al≈øo ≈øeveral Plates after the Life, of his own Invention, which are all very admirable.

It is al≈øo True that toward the End of the la≈øt Age, Augu≈øtin Carrache advanced Graving beyond tho≈øe who had preceeded him; and that which farther di≈øtingui≈øh'd him from other Gravers, was the excellence and correctne≈øs of his De≈øign. For he had ≈øo pa≈ø≈øionate a De≈øire to make tho≈øe Arts Flouri≈øh, that he with his Illu≈øtrious Brother Hannibal, and their Cou≈øin Lewis Carrache e≈øtabli≈øh'd an Academy at Bologna.

It was this Famous School which brought up the mo≈øt Ingenious De≈øigners and Famous Painters of Bologna, who maintained the excellence of De≈øigning and Painting, in the highe≈øt Pitch tho≈øe Noble Arts have arrived to ≈øince their revival. It is to the≈øe Carraches we are obliged, for having hindred Painting, at the beginning of our Age, from a total Declen≈øion at Rome, which then threatned it, by rea≈øon that the Manneri≈øts of the School of Jo≈øeph Arpino, and tho≈øe of the School of Caravage, who were their Antagoni≈øts, got the better of tho≈øe who followed the Gu≈øto of the Ancients, and the noble Manner of Raphael. But at la≈øt the Ingenious Di≈øciples of the Academy of the Carraches, got the day both from the one and the other, and Ree≈øtabli≈øhed the true way of De≈øigning and Painting;
which has ever ≈øince happily continued down to us: And throughout all this Age of 1600 the≈øe Arts have appear'd and continued in Perfefection, which ≈øhall be the Subject of the Second Part of the Hi≈øtory of the≈øe Arts.

By the Ingenious Gravers we have mentioned in this la≈øt Chapter, it may be noted that we reckon Graving among the Arts that depend on De≈øigning and Painting, as Con≈øequent to them, for the Painters fir≈øt began the right Practice of it, and to advance it to that high Degree wherein now we ≈øee it.

We may moreover ≈øee that the Way of making the Punchions and Dies for ≈øtriking of Medals, is one Sort of Graving, which depends on Sculpture: And that the mo≈øt Excellent Gravers have been all well ver≈øed both in Sculpture and Painting; for they never Grave their Coins, till they have fir≈øt modell'd their Works: Thus Sculpture preceeds Graving. The ingenious Medalli≈øts in the Time of Henry the IId and Henry the IVth, were Sculptors; and we commonly hold, that John Goujon made the fine≈øt Medals of this fir≈øt King, and of Catharine de Medicis which are to be ≈øeen. John Rondelle and E≈øtienne Lanne are al≈øo Famous, who made the Coin under Henry the II, and tho≈øe fine Te≈øtoons of that Prince.

As to the Medals of Henry the IVth, the fine≈øt are tho≈øe of . . . . . . du Pres, who was an ingenious Graver, and excellent Sculptor; the Ba≈øs Relief which is to be ≈øeen in the King of Sicily's Street in Paris is a Proof of this. Graving has been always very much E≈øteemed, and gain'd a great deal of Credit, as well as the other Arts of De≈øigning; the Emperor Commodus be≈øides De≈øigning which he learnt, learnt al≈øo to Grave, as we have ≈øhew'd in the beginning of the Second Book: And we can't but believe, that his End therein was to make Medals, the Knowledge whereof has always been ≈øo much E≈øteemed both among the Ancients and Moderns; and that which farther proves this, is, that we find no other ways of Graving among the Ancients, than that of Graving very deep for making Medals, and Graving fine Stones for Rings, and others for Seals, which are often to be met with in the Cabinets of the Curious.
